titleStmt.title: The trissotetras: or, a most exquisite table for resolving all manner of triangles, whether plaine or sphericall, rectangular or obliquangular, with greater facility, then ever hitherto hath been practised: most necessary for all such as would attaine to the exact knowledge of fortification, dyaling, navigation, surveying, architecture, the art of shadowing, taking of heights, and distances, the use of both the globes, perspective, the skill of making the maps, the theory of the planets, the calculating of their motions, and of all other astronomicall computations whatsoever. Now lately invented, and perfected, explained, commented on, and with all possible brevity, and perspicuity, in the hiddest, and most re-searched mysteries, from the very first grounds of the science it selfe, proved, and convincingly demonstrated. / By Sir Thomas Urquhart of Cromartie Knight. Published for the benefit of those that are mathematically affected.
titleStmt.author: Urquhart, Thomas, Sir, 1611-1660.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRISSOTETRAS: OR A MOST EXQUISITE TABLE FOR Re≈øolving all manner of Triangles, whether Plaine or Sphericall, Rectangular or Obliquangular, with greater facility, then ever hitherto hath been practi≈øed: Mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for all ≈øuch as would attaine to the exact knowledge of Fortification, Dyaling, Navigation, Surveying, Architecture, the Art of Shadowing, taking of Heights, and Di≈øtances, the u≈øe of both the Globes, Per≈øpective, the skill of making of Maps, the Theory of the Planets, the calculating of their motions, and of all other A≈øtronomicall computations what≈øoever.

Now lately invented, and perfected, explained, commented on, and, with all po≈ø≈øible brevity, and per≈øpicuity, in the hidde≈øt, and mo≈øt re-≈øearched my≈øteries, from the very fir≈øt grounds of the Science it ≈øelfe, proved, and convincingly demon≈øtrated.
By Sir THOMAS URQUHART of Cromartie Knight.
Publi≈øhed for the benefit of tho≈øe that are Mathematically affected.
LONDON, Printed by Iames Young. 1645.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE, And mo≈øt noble LADY, My deare and loving Mother, the Lady DOWAGER of Cromartie.
div.p:
FILIALL duty being the more binding in me, that I doe owe it to the be≈øt of Mothers; if in the di≈øcharge thereof I ob≈øerve not the u≈øuall manner of other ≈øonnes, I am the le≈ø≈øe to blame, that their obligation is not ≈øo great as mine: Therefore in that doe
pre≈øume to imprint your Ladi≈øhips name in the Fronti≈øpiece of this Book, and proffer unto you a Dedication of that, which is beyond the capacity of other Ladies; my boldne≈ø≈øe therein is the more excu≈øable, that in your per≈øon the mo≈øt vertuous Woman in the world is intreated to Patronize that, which by the learnede≈øt men may happily be peru≈øed.

I am confident (Madam) that your gracious acceptance of this Pre≈øent is the more ea≈øily obtainable, in that it is a grand-child of your own, whom I thus make tender of, to be ≈øheltered under the favor of your protection; and that unto your Ladi≈øhip it will not be the more unwelcome, for proceeding from the braines of him, who≈øe body is not more yours by generation, then by a mo≈øt equitable purcha≈øe are the faculties of his mind; the dominion which over my better halfe you, by your goodne≈ø≈øe, have acquired, being, in regard of my obedience, no le≈ø≈øe voluntary, then that of the other is for procreation naturall.

Thus (Madam) unto you doe I totally belong, but ≈øo, as that tho≈øe exteriour parts of mine, which by birth are from your Ladi≈øhip derived, cannot be more fortunate in this their ≈øubjection (notwith≈øtanding the egregious advantages of bloud, and
con≈øanguinity thereby to them accruing) then my ≈øelfe am happy (as from my heart I doe acknowledge it) in the ju≈øt right, your Ladi≈øhip hath to the eternall po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of the never-dying powers of my ≈øoule. For, though (Soveraignty excepted) there be none in this I≈øland more honourably de≈øcended then is your Ladi≈øhip, nor who≈øe progenitors, the≈øe many ages pa≈øt, have been (on either ≈øide) of a more Noble extraction: Yet, laying apart Nobility, beauty, wealth, parentage, and friends, which (together with many other gifts of fortune) have hitherto ≈øerved to adorn your Ladi≈øhip beyond others of your ≈øex, who for all the≈øe have been de≈øervedly renowned; and (in ≈øome mea≈øure) not e≈øteeming that properly to be yours, the receiving whereof did not altogether depend upon your owne election: it is the trea≈øure of tho≈øe excellent graces, wherewith inwardly you are enriched, that, in prai≈øing of your Ladi≈øhip is mo≈øt to be pitch'd upon, and for the which you are mo≈øt highly to be commended; ≈øeeing by the means of them, you, from your tendere≈øt yeeres upwards, untill this time, in the ≈øtate of both ∆≤irginity and Matrimony, have ≈øo con≈øtantly, and indefatigably proceeded in the cour≈øe of vertue, with ≈øuch alacrity fixed your gallant thoughts on the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe
thereof, and thereunto ≈øo firmly and cheerefully devoted all your words and actions, as if righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe in your Ladi≈øhip had been an inbred quality, and that in your Will there had beene no aptitude of declining from the way of rea≈øon.

This much is ≈øufficiently well known to tho≈øe, that have at any time enjoyed the honour of your Ladi≈øhips conver≈øation, by who≈øe mo≈øt unpartiall reports, the Splendour of your reputation is both in this, and foraine Nations accounted precious, in the minds even of tho≈øe, that have never ≈øeen you. But in ≈øo much more e≈øpecially, doe the mo≈øt judicious of either ≈øex admire the rare and ≈øublime endowments, wherewith your Ladi≈øhip is qualified, that (as a patterne of perfection, worthy to be univer≈øally followed) other Ladies (of what dignity ≈øoever) are truly by them e≈øteemed of the choi≈øer merit, the nearer they draw to the Paragon propo≈øed, and re≈øemble your Ladi≈øhip; for that, by vertue of your beloved ≈øociety, your neighbouring Counte≈ø≈øes, and other greater Dames of your kindred and acquaintance, become the more illu≈øtrious in your imitation; amid≈øt whom, as Cynthia among≈øt the ob≈øcurer Planets, your Ladi≈øhip ≈øhines, and darteth the Angelick rayes of your matchle≈ø≈øe example
on the ≈øpirits of tho≈øe, who by their good Genius have been brought into your favourable pre≈øence to be enlightned by them.

Now (Madam) le≈øt, by in≈øi≈øting any longer upon this ≈øtraine, I ≈øhould ≈øeeme to offend that mode≈øty, and humility, which (without derogating from your heroick vertues) are ≈øeated in a con≈øiderable place of your ≈øoule, I will here, in all ≈øubmi≈øsion, mo≈øt humbly take my leave of your Ladi≈øhip, and be≈øeech Almighty God, that it may plea≈øe his Divine Maje≈øty ≈øo to ble≈ø≈øe your Ladi≈øhip with continuance of dayes, that the ≈øonnes of tho≈øe whom I have not as yet begot, may attaine to the happine≈ø≈øe of pre≈øenting unto your Ladi≈øhip a brain-babe of more ≈øufficiencie and con≈øequence; and that your Ladi≈øhip may live with as much health, and pro≈øperity, to accept thereof, and cheri≈øh it then, as (I hope) you doe now, at your vouch≈øafing to receive this, which (though di≈øproportionable, both to your Ladi≈øhips high de≈øerts, and to that fervencie of willingne≈ø≈øe in me, ≈øometime to make offer of what is of better worth, and more ≈øutable to the grandour of your acceptance) in all ≈øincerity of heart (confiding in that candour and ingenuity, wherby your Ladi≈øhip is accu≈øtomed to value gifts,
according to the intention of the giver) and in all duty, and lowline≈ø≈øe of mind, together with my ≈øelfe in whole, and all my be≈øt endeavours, I tender unto your Ladi≈øhip, as becometh, (Madam)

closer.signed: Your Ladi≈øhips mo≈øt affectionate Sonne and humble ≈øervant, THOMAS URQUHART.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: TO write of Trigonometry, and not make mention of the illu≈øtrious Lord Neper of Marchi≈øton, the inventer of Logarithms, were to be unmindfull of him that is our daily Benefactor; the≈øe artificiall numbers by him fir≈øt excogitated and perfected, being of ≈øuch incomparable u≈øe, that, by them, we may operate more in one day, and with le≈ø≈øe danger of errour, then can be done without them in the ≈øpace of a whole week. A ≈øecret which would have beene ≈øo precious to Antiquity, that Pythagoras, all the ≈øeven wi≈øe men of Greece, Archimedes, Socrates, Plato, Euclid, and Ari≈øtotle, had (if coaevals) joyntly adored him, and unanimou≈øly concurred to the deifying of the revealer of ≈øo great a My≈øtery: and truly (be≈øides them) a great many other learned men, who for the laboriou≈øne≈ø≈øe of long and various Multiplications, Divi≈øions, and Radicall extractions of ≈øeverall ≈øorts, were deterred from the pro≈øecuting, and divulging of their knowledge in the chiefe≈øt, and mo≈øt noble parts of the Mathematicks, would have left behind them diver≈øe exqui≈øite Volumes, of an incomprehen≈øible value, if the Arithmetical equality of difference, agreeable to every continued Geometricall proportion, had been made known unto them.

Wherefore, I am infallibly per≈øwaded, that, in the e≈øtimation of ≈øcientifically di≈øpo≈øed ≈øpirits, the Philo≈øophers ≈øtone is but tra≈øh to this invention, which will alwayes (in their judicious opinions) be accounted of more worth to the Mathematicall world, then was the finding out of America, to the King of Spaine; or the di≈øcovery of the neare≈øt
way to the Ea≈øt-indies, would be to the Northerly occidentall Merchants.

What the merit then of the Author is, let the mo≈øt envious judge: for my owne part, I doe not prai≈øe him ≈øo much, for that he is my Compatriot, as I mu≈øt extoll the happine≈ø≈øe of my Countrey, for having produced ≈øo brave a ≈øpark, in whom alone (I may with confidence averre, it is more glorious, then if it had beene the conquering Kingdome of five hundred potent Nations: for, by how much the gifts of the mind, are more excellent then tho≈øe of either body or fortune; by ≈øo much the divine effects of the faculties thereof, are of greater con≈øequence, then what is performed by meer force of Armes, or chance of Warre.

I might ≈øay more in commendation of this gallant man, but that my di≈øcour≈øe being directed to the Reader, he will po≈ø≈øibly expect to be entertained with ≈øome other purpo≈øe then Encomia≈øticks; and therefore, to undeceive him of tho≈øe hopes (if any ≈øuch there be) I will a≈ø≈øure him, that to no other end I did require his ob≈øervance here, but to be informed by me of the laudable endowments of that honourable Baron, who≈øe eminencie above others (wher-ever he be ≈øpoke of) de≈øerveth ≈øuch an ample Elogie by it ≈øelfe, that the paper, graced with the receiving of his name and character, ≈øhould not be blurred with the cour≈øe impre≈ø≈øion of any other ≈øtuffe.

However the Reader ought not to conceive ami≈ø≈øe for his being detained ≈øo long upon this Eulogi≈øtick ≈øubject, without the variety of any peculiar in≈øtruction be≈øtowed on him; ≈øeeing I am certaine there is nothing more advantagious to him, or that more efficaciou≈øly can tend to his improvement, then the imitation of that admirable Gentleman, who≈øe immortall fame, in ≈øpite of time, will out-la≈øt all ages, and look eternity in the face.

div.head: An Epaenetick and Doxologetick Expre≈ø≈øe, in commendation of this Book, and the Author thereof.
div.p: SEeing Trigonometry, which hand≈øomly unlocketh the choyce≈øt, and mo≈øt intime my≈øteries of the Mathematicks, hath beene hitherto expo≈øed to the world in a method, who≈øe intricacy deterreth many from adventuring on it; We are all, and every one of us, by duty bound to acknowledge our ≈øelves beholding to the Author of this Treati≈øe; who, by reducing all the ≈øecrets of that noble Science into a mo≈øt exqui≈øite order, hath ≈øo facilitated the way to the Learner, that in ≈øeven weeks, at mo≈øt, he may attaine to more knowledge therein, then otherwi≈øe he could doe for his heart in the ≈øpace of a twelve-moneth: And who, for the better encouragement of the ≈øtudious, hath ≈øo gentilely expatiated his ≈øpirits upon all its Actioms, Principles, Analogies, precepts, and whole ≈øubjected matter; that this Mathematicall Tractate doth no le≈ø≈øe be≈øpeak him a good Poet, and good Orator, then by his elaboured Poems he hath ≈øhowne him≈øelfe already a good Philo≈øopher, and Mathematician.

Thus doth the various mixture of mo≈øt excellent qualities
in him, give ≈øuch evidence of the tran≈øcendent faculties of his mind, that, as the Mu≈øes never yet in≈øpired ≈øublimer conceptions in a more refined ≈øtile, then is to be found in the accurate ≈øtrain of his mo≈øt ingenious Epigrams: ≈øo, on the other part, are the ab≈øtru≈øe≈øt difficulties of this Science by him ≈øo neatly unfolded, and with ≈øuch exactne≈ø≈øe hath he re≈øolved the harde≈øt, and mo≈øt intangled doubts thereof; that, I may ju≈øtly ≈øay, what prai≈øe (in his Epi≈øtle, or rather Preface, to the Reader) he hath beene plea≈øed (out of his ingenuity, to confer on the learned, and honourable Neper, doth, without any diminution, in every jot, as duly belong unto him≈øelfe.

For, I am certainly per≈øwaded, he that u≈øeth Logarithms, ≈øhall not gaine ≈øo much time on the Worker by the naturall Sines and Tangents, as, by vertue of this ≈øuccinct manner of calculation, ≈øhall be got on him that knoweth it not, how compendiou≈øly ≈øoever el≈øe, with Addition and Subtraction, or Addition alone, he frame his Computations. However, he who, together with that of the Logarithms, maketh u≈øe of this invention, is in a way which will bring him ≈øo ≈øtraight and readily to the perfect practice of Trigonometry, that, compared with the old beaten path, trod upon by Regiomontanus, Ptolomy, and other ancient Mathematicians, it is like the Sea voyage, in regard of that by Land, betwixt the two Pillars of (Hercules commonly called, the Straits of Gibraltar) whereof the one is but of ≈øix houres ≈øailing at mo≈øt, and the other a journey of ≈øeven thou≈øand long miles.

If we then con≈øider how a great many, de≈øpairing ever to get out (if once entred) of the confu≈øed ob≈øcurity wherein the doctrine of Triangles hath beene from time to time involved, have rather contented them≈øelves barely with Scale and Compa≈ø≈øe, and other mechanick tooles and in≈øtruments, to pro≈øecute their operations, and in any rea≈øonable mea≈øure to glance ≈øomewhat neare the truth, then, thorough ≈øo many pe≈øterments, and har≈øh incumbrances, to touch it to a point, in its mo≈øt indivi≈øible and infallible reality. And how others, for all their being more indu≈øtrious, in proving their Conclu≈øions by the Mediums from which they are nece≈ø≈øarily inferr'd, are neverthele≈ø≈øe (even when they have be≈øtowed half an age in the Trigonometricall practice) oftentimes ≈øo farre to ≈øeek, that, without a great deale of premeditation advi≈øement, and recollecting of them≈øelves, they know not how to di≈øcu≈ø≈øe ≈øome queries, corollaries, problems, con≈øectaries, proportions, wayes of perpendicular falling, and other ≈øuch like occurring debatable matters, incident to the ≈øcientifick mea≈øuring of Triangles; We cannot choo≈øe (the≈øe things being maturely perpended) but be much taken with the pregnancy of this device, whereby we ≈øhall ≈øooner hit to a minut upon the verity of an Angle or Side demanded, and trace it to the very ≈øource and originall, from whence it flowes, then another mechanically ≈øhall be able to come within three degrees thereof, although he cannot, for the ≈øame little he doth, afford any rea≈øon at all; And ≈øo ≈øuddenly re≈øolve any Trigonometricall que≈øtion (without
paines or labour, how perplexed ≈øoever it be) with all the dependances thereto belonging, as if it were a knowledge meerly infu≈øed from above, and revealed by the peculiar in≈øpiration of ≈øome favourable Angel.

Be≈øides the≈øe advantages, admini≈øtred unto us by the meanes of this exqui≈øite Book, this maine commodity accreweth to the diligent Peru≈øers of it, that, in≈øtead of three quarters of a yeere, u≈øually by Profe≈ø≈øors allowed to their Schollers for the right conceiving of this Science, which (notwith≈øtanding) through any little di≈øcontinuance, is by them ≈øo apt to be forgotten, that the expence of a week or two will hardly ≈øuffice to re≈øeat it in their memories; they ≈øhall not need, by this method, to be≈øtow above a moneth, and with ≈øuch ea≈øe and facility for retention, when they have learned and acquired it, that, if multiplicity of bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, or ≈øerious plodding upon other ≈øtudies happen to blot it out of their minds, they may as firmly recover in one quarter of an hour the whole knowledge and remembrance thereof, as when they had it be≈øt, and were mo≈øt punctually ver≈øed in it.

A ≈øecret (in my opinion) ≈øo precious, that (as the Author ≈øpoke of Marchi≈øton) I may with the like pertinencie avouch of him, that his Countrey and kindred would not have been more honoured by him, had he purcha≈øed millions of gold, and ≈øeverall rich territories of a great and va≈øt extent; then for this ≈øubtile and divine invention, which will out-la≈øt the continuance of any inheritance, and remaine fre≈øh in the under≈øtandings

of men of profound Literature, when hou≈øes and po≈ø≈øe≈øsions will change their owners, the wealthy become poor, and the children of the needy enjoy the trea≈øures of tho≈øe, who≈øe heires are impoveri≈øhed.

Therefore, ≈øeeing for the many-fold u≈øes thereof in divers Arts and Sciences, in ≈øpeculation and practice, peace and war, ≈øport and earne≈øt, with the admirable furtherances we reape by it, in the knowledge of Sea and Land, and Heaven and Earth, it cannot be otherwi≈øe then permanent, together with the Authors fame, ≈øo long as any of tho≈øe endure; I will (God willing) in the ruines of all the≈øe, and when time it ≈øelfe is expired, in te≈øtimony of my thankfulne≈ø≈øe in particular for ≈øo great a benefit, (if after the Re≈øurrection, there be any complementall affability) expre≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe then, as I doe now,

closer.signed: The Authors mo≈øt affectionate, and mo≈øt humbly devoted ≈øervant J. A.

That the Schemes and Types of Triangulary Analogies are not ≈øeated in the roomes, where they are treated of, I purpo≈øely have done it; to the end, that being all perceived at one view, their multiplicity (which would appeare confu≈øed in their ‚Ä¢ i≈øper≈øed method) might ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ot any way di≈øcourage „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ der: be≈øides that, this their ‚Ä¢ eing together in their ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ order, and rancked ‚Ä¢ ecording to the exigence of the Sides or Angles, is ≈øuch a furtherance to the memory, and illu≈øtration to the judgement, that it maketh Trigonometry, which of all Sciences was accounted the ab≈øtru≈øe≈øt, to be in effect the mo≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ and „Äà‚óä„Äâ .

div.head: In Eruditum D. Thomae ∆≤rquharti equitis Tri≈ø≈øotetrados librum.

Vel tibi ≈øi cordi e≈øt terrae ≈øpatia ampla metiri,

Et ≈øine Neptuno nare per alta vales.

div.head: POSITIONS.
div.p: EVery Circle is divided into three hundred and ≈øixty parts, called Degrees, whereof each one is Sexage≈øimated, Sub≈øexage≈øimated, Re≈øub≈øexage≈øimated, and Bire≈øub≈øexage≈øimated, in Minutes, Seconds, Thirds, Fourths, and ≈øo far forth as any Computi≈øt is plea≈øed to proceed for the exactne≈ø≈øe of a Re≈øearch, in the calculation of any Orbiculary Dimen≈øion.

2. As Degrees are the mea≈øure of Arches, ≈øo are they of Angles; but that tho≈øe are called Circumferentiall, the≈øe Angulary Degrees, each whereof is the three hundred and ≈øixtieth part of four right Angles, which are nothing el≈øe but the ≈øurface of a Plain to any point circumjacent; for any ≈øpace what≈øoever about a point, is divided in 360. parts: And the better to conceive the Analogie that is betwixt the≈øe two ≈øorts of graduall Mea≈øures, we mu≈øt know, that there is the ≈øame proportion of any Angle to 4. right Angles, as of an arch of ≈øo many circumferential degrees to the whole circumference.

3. Hence is it, that the ≈øame number ≈øerves the Angle, and the Arch that vaults it, and that divers quantities are mea≈øured (as it were) with the ≈øame graduall mea≈øure. Angles and Arches then are Analogicall, and the ≈øame rea≈øon is of both.

4. Seeing any given proportion may be found in numbers, and that any two quantities have the ≈øame proportion that the two numbers have, according to the which they are mea≈øured: if for the mea≈øuring of Triangles there mu≈øt be certain proportions of all the parts of a Triangle, to one another known, and tho≈øe proportions explained in numbers it is mo≈øt certain, all Magnitudes, being Figures at lea≈øt in power, and all Figures either Triangles, or Triangled, that the Arithmeticall Solution of any Geometricall que≈øtion, dependeth on the Doctrine of Triangles.

5. And though the proportion betwixt the parts of a Triangle cannot be without ≈øome errour; becau≈øe of crooked lines to right lines, and of crooked lines among≈øt them≈øelves, the rea≈øon is in≈øcrutable, no man being able to finde out the exact proportion of the Diameter to the Circumference: yet both in plain Triangles, where the mea≈øure of the Angles is of a different ≈øpecies from the ≈øides, and in Sphericalls, wherein both the Angles and ≈øides are of a circular nature, crooked lines are in ≈øome mea≈øure reduced to right lines by the definition of quantity which right lines, viz. Sines, Tangents,
and Secants, applyed to a Circle have in re≈øpect of the Radius, o ‚Ä¢ half-Diameter.

6. And therefore, though the Circles Quadrature be not found out, it being in our power to make the Diameter, or the ≈øemi-Diameter, which is the Radius of as many parts as we plea≈øe, and being ≈øure ≈øo much the more that the Radius be taken, the error will be the le≈ø≈øer; for albeit the Sines, Tangents and Secants, be irrationall thereto for the mo≈øt part, and their proportion inexplicable by any number what≈øoever, whither whole or broken: yet if they be rightly made, they will be ≈øuch, as that in them all no number will be different from the truth by an integer, or unity of tho≈øe parts, whereof the Radius is taken: which is ≈øo exactly done by ≈øome, e≈øpecially by Peti≈øcus, who a≈ø≈øumed a Radius of twenty ≈øix places, that according to his ≈øupputation (the Diameter of the Earth being known, and the Globe thereof ≈øuppo≈øed to be perfectly round) one ≈øhould not fail in the dimen≈øion of its whole Circuit, the nine hundreth thou≈øand ≈øcantling of the Million part of an Inch, and yet not be able, for all that, to mea≈øure it without ami≈ø≈øe; for ≈øo indivi≈øible the truth of a thing is, that come you never ≈øo neer it, unle≈ø≈øe you hit upon it ju≈øt to a point, there is an errour ≈øtill.

div.head: DEFINITIONS.
div.p: A Cord, or Subten≈øe, is a right line, drawn from the one extremity to the other of an Arch.
2. A right Sine is the half Cord of the double Arch propo≈øed, and from one extremity of the Arch falleth perpendicularly on the Radius, pa≈ø≈øing by the other end thereof.
3. A Tangent is a right line, drawn from the Secant by one end of the Arch, perpendicularly on the extremity of the Diameter, pa≈ø≈øing by the other end of the ≈øaid Arch.
4. A Secant is the prolonged Radius, which pa≈ø≈øeth by the upper extremity of the Arch, till it meet with the ≈øine Tangent of the ≈øaid Arch.
5. Complement is the difference betwixt the le≈ø≈øer Arch, and a Quadrant, or betwixt a right Angle and an Acute.
6. The complement to a ≈øemi-Circle, is the difference betwixt the half-Circumference and any Arch le≈ø≈øer, or betwixt two right Angles, and an Oblique Angle, whither blunt or ≈øharp.

7. The ver≈øed ≈øine is the remainder of the Radius, the ≈øine
Complement being ≈øubtracted from it, and though great u≈øe may be made of the ver≈øed ≈øines, for finding out of the Angles by the ≈øides, and ≈øides by the Angles: yet in Logarithmicall calculations they are altogether u≈øele≈ø≈øe, and therefore in my Tri≈ø≈øotetras there is no mention made of them.

8. In Amblygono≈øphericall ‚Ä¢ , which admit both of an Extrin≈øecall, and Intrin≈øecall demi≈ø≈øion of the perpendicular, nineteen ≈øeverall parts are to be con≈øidered: viz. The Perpendicular, the Subtendentall, the Subtendentine, two Co≈øubtendents, the Ba≈øall, the Ba≈øidion, the chief Segment of the Ba≈øe, two Coba≈øes, the double Verticall, the Verticall, the Verticaline, two Coverticalls, the next Cathetoppo≈øite, the prime Cathetoppo≈øite, and the two Cocathetoppo≈øites: fourteen whereof, (to wit) the Subtendentall, the Subtendentine, the Co≈øubtendents, the Ba≈øall, the Ba≈øidion, the Coba≈øes, the Verticall, the Verticaline, the Coverticalls, and Cocathetoppo≈øites, are called the fir≈øt, either Subtendent, Ba≈øe, Topangle, or Cocathetoppo≈øite, whither in the great Triangle or the little, or in the Correctangle, if they be ingredients of that Rectangular, whereof mo≈øt parts are known, which parts are alwayes a Subtendent and a Cathetoppo≈øite: but if they be in the other Triangle, they are called the ≈øecond Subtendents, Ba≈øes, and ≈øo forth.
9. The externall double Verticall is included by the Perpendicular, and Subtendentall, and divided by the Subtendentine: the internall is included by co≈øubtendents, and divided by the Perpendicular.

div.head: APODICTICKS.
div.p: THe Angles made by a right Line, falling on another right Line, are equall to two right Angles; becau≈øe every Angle being mea≈øured by an Arch, or part of a Circumference, and a right Angle by ninety Degrees, if upon the middle of the ground line, as Center, be de≈øcribed a ≈øemi-Circle, it will be the mea≈øure of the Angles, comprehended betwixt the falling, and ≈øu≈øtaining lines.

2. Hence it is, that the four oppo≈øite Angles made by one line, cro≈ø≈øing another, are always each to its own oppo≈øite equall; for if upon the point of Inter≈øection, as Center, be de≈øcribed a Circle, every two of tho≈øe Angles will fill up the ≈øemi-Circle; therefore the fir≈øt and ≈øecond will be equall to the ≈øecond and third, and con≈øequently the ≈øecond, which is the common Angle to both the≈øe couples being removed, the fir≈øt will remain equall to the
third, and by the ≈øame rea≈øon, the ≈øecond to the fourth, which was to be demon≈øtrated.

3. If a right line falling upon two other right lines, make the alternat Angles equall, the≈øe lines mu≈øt needs be Paralell; for if they did meet, the alternat Angles would not be equall; becau≈øe in all plain Triangles, the outward Angle is greater, then any of the remote inward Angles, which is proved by the fir≈øt.

4. If one of the ≈øides of a Triangle be produced, the outward Angle is equall to both the inner, and oppo≈øite Angles together; becau≈øe according to the acclining or declining of the conterminall ≈øide, is left an Angulary ≈øpace, for the receiving of a paralell to the oppo≈øite ≈øide, in the point of who≈øe occour≈øe at the ba≈øe, the Exterior Angle is divided into two, which for their like, and alternat ≈øituation with the two Interior Angles, are equall each to its own conform to the nature of Angles, made by a right line cro≈ø≈øing divers paralells.

5. From hence we gather, that the three Angles of a plain Triangle, are equall to two rights; for the two inward, being equall to the Externall one, and there remaining of the three, but one, which was proved in the fir≈øt Apodictick, to be the Externall Angles complement to two rights; it mu≈øt needs fall forth (what are equall to a third, being equall among≈øt them≈øelves) that the three Angles of a plain Triangle, are equall to two right Angles, the which we undertook to prove.
6. By the ≈øame rea≈øon, the two acute of a Rectangled plain Triangle, are equall to one right Angle, and any one of them, the others complement thereto.

7. In every Circle, an Angle from the Center, is two in the Limb, both of them having one part of the Circumference for ba≈øe; for being an Externall Angle, and con≈øequently equall to both the Intrin≈øecall Angles, and therefore equall to one another; becau≈øe of their being ≈øubtended by equall ba≈øes, viz. the ≈øemi-Diameters, it mu≈øt needs be the double of the fore≈øaid Angle in the limb.

8. Triangles ≈øtanding between two paralells, upon one and the fame ba≈øe, are equall; for the Identity of the ba≈øe, whereon they are ≈øeated, together with the Equidi≈øtance of the Lines, within the which they are confined, maketh them of ≈øuch a nature, that how long ≈øo ever the line paralell to the ba≈øe be protracted, the Diagonall cutting of in one off the Triangles, as much of bredth, as it
gains of length, (the ones lo≈ø≈øe accruing to the profit of the other) Quantifies them both to an equality, the thing we did intend to prove.
9. Hence do we inferre, that Triangles betwixt two paralells, are in the ≈øame proportion with their ba≈øes.

10. Therefore if in a Triangle, be drawn a paralell to any of the ≈øides, it divideth the other ≈øides, through which it pa≈ø≈øeth proportionally; for be≈øides that it maketh the four ≈øegments, to be four ba≈øes, it becomes (if two Diagonall lines be extended from the ends thereof, to the ends of its paralell) a common ba≈øe to two equall Triangles, to which two, the Triangle of the fir≈øt two ≈øegments, having reference according to the difference of their ba≈øes, and the≈øe two being equall, as it is to the one, ≈øo mu≈øt it be to the other, and therefore the fir≈øt ba≈øe, mu≈øt be to the ≈øecond, (which are the Segments of one ≈øide of the Triangle) as the third to the fourth, (which are the Segments of the ≈øecond) all which was to be demon≈øtrated.

11. From hence do we collect, that Equiangled Triangles have their ≈øides about the equall Angles proportionall to one another. This ≈øayes Peti≈øcus, is the golden Foundation, and chief ground of Trigonometry.
12. An Angle in a ≈øemi-Circle is right; becau≈øe it is equall to both the Angles at the ba≈øe, which (by cutting the Diameter in two) is perceivable to any.

13. Of four proportionall lines, the Rectangled figure, made of the two extreames, is equall to the Rectangular, compo≈øed of the means; for as four and one, are equall to two and three, by an Arithmeticall proportion: and the fourth term Geometrically exceeding, or being le≈ø≈øe then the third, as the ≈øecond is more, or le≈ø≈øe then the fir≈øt; what the fourth hath, or wanteth, from and above the third, is ≈øupplyed, or impaired by the Surplu≈øage, or deficiency of the fir≈øt from and above the ≈øecond: The≈øe Analogies being ≈øtill taken in a Geometricall way, make the oblong of the two middle, equall to that of the extreams, which was to be proved.

14. In all plain Rectangled Triangles, the Ambients are equall in power to the Subtendent; for by demitting from the right Angle a Perpendicular, there will ari≈øe two Correctangles, from who≈øe Equiangularity with the great Rectangle, will proceed ≈øuch a proportion among≈øt the Homologall ≈øides, of all the three, that if you ≈øet them right in the rule, beginning your Analogy at the main Subtendent,
(≈øeeing the including ≈øides of the totall Rectangle, prove Subtendents in the partiall Correctangles, and the ba≈øes of tho≈øe Rectanglets, the Segments of the great Subtendent) it will fall out, that as the main Subtendent is to his ba≈øe, on either ≈øide (for either of the legs of a Rectangled Triangle, in reference to one another, is both ba≈øe and Perpendicular) ≈øo the ≈øame ba≈øes, which are Subtendents in the le≈ø≈øer Rectangles, are to their ba≈øes, the Segment, of the prime Subtendent: Then by the Golden rule we find, that the multiplying of the middle termes (which is nothing el≈øe, but the ≈øquaring of the comprehending ≈øides of the prime Rectangular) affords two products, equall to the oblongs made of the great Subtendent, and his re≈øpective Segments, the aggregat whereof by equation is the ≈øame with the ≈øquare of the chief Subtendent, or Hypotenu≈øa, which was to be demon≈øtrated.

15. In every totall ≈øquare, the ≈øupplements about the partiall, and Interior ≈øquares, are equall the one to the other; for by drawing a Diagonall line, the great ≈øquare being divided into two equall Triangles, becau≈øe of their ≈øtanding on equall ba≈øes betwixt two paralells, by the ninth Apodictick, it is evident, that in either of the≈øe great Triangles, there being two partiall ones, equall to the two of the other, each to his own, by the ≈øame Rea≈øon of the ninth: If from equall things (viz. the totall Triangles) be taken equall things (to wit, the two pairs of partiall Triangles) equall things mu≈øt needs remain, which are the fore≈øaid ≈øupplements, who≈øe equality I undertook to prove,

16. If a right line cut into two equall parts be increa≈øed, the ≈øquare made of the additonall line, and one of the Bi≈øegments, joyned in one, le≈ø≈øe by the Square of the half of the line Bi≈øected, is equall to the oblong contained under the prolonged line, and the line of Continuation; for if annexedly to the longe≈øt ≈øide of the propo≈øed oblong, be de≈øcribed the fore≈øaid Square, there will jet out beyond the Quadrat Figure, a ≈øpace or Rectangle, which for being powered by the Bi≈øegment and Additionall line, will be equall to the neere≈øt ≈øupplement, and con≈øequently to the other (the equality of ≈øupplements being proved by the la≈øt Apodictick) by vertue whereof, a Gnomon in the great Square, lacking nothing of its whole Area, but the ≈øpace of the ≈øquare of the Bi≈øected line, is apparent to equalize the Parallelogram propo≈øed, which was to be demon≈øtrated.

17. From hence proceedeth this Sequell, that if from any point without a circle, two lines cutting it be protracted to the other extremity thereof, making two cords, the oblongs contained under the totall lines, and the exce≈ø≈øe of the Subten≈øes, are equall one to another; for whether any of the lines pa≈ø≈øe through the Center, or not, if the Subten≈øes be Bi≈øected, ≈øeeing all lines from the Center fall Perpendicularly upon the Chordall point of Bi≈øection (becau≈øe the two ≈øemi-Diameters, and Bi≈øegments ≈øub≈øterned under equall Angles, in two Triangles evince the equality of the third Angle, to the third, by the fift Apodictick, which two Angles being made by the falling of one right line upon another, mu≈øt needs be right by the tenth definition of the fir≈øt of Euchilde) the Bucarnon of Pythagoras, demon≈øtrated in my fourteenth Apodictick, will by Quadro≈øubductions of Ambients, from one another, and their Quadrobiquadrequation ‚Ä¢ with the Hypotenu≈øa, together with other Analogies of equation with the powers of like Rectangular Triangles, comprehended within the ≈øame circle, manife≈øt the equality of long Squares, or oblongs Radically meeting in an Exterior point, and made of the prolonged Subten≈øes, and the lines of interception, betwixt the limb of the circle, and the point of concour≈øe, quod probandum fuit.

18. Now to look back on the eleaventh Apodictick, where according to Peti≈øcus, I ≈øaid that upon the mutuall proportion of the ≈øides of Equiangled Triangles, is founded the whole Science of Trigonometry, I do here re≈øpeak it, and with confidence maintain the truth thereof; becau≈øe, be≈øides many others, it is the ground of the≈øe Sub≈øequent Theorems: 1. The right ≈øine of an Arch, is to its co-≈øine, as the Radius to the co-tangent of the ≈øaid Arch. 2. The co-≈øine of an Arch, is to its ≈øine, as the Radius to the Tangent of the ≈øaid Arch. 3. The Sines, and co-Secants: the Secants, and co-Sines: and the Tangents, and co-Tangents, are reciprocally proportionall. 4. The Radius is a mean proportionall, betwixt the Sine, and co-Secant: the Secant, and co-Sine: and the Tangent, and co-Tangent: The verity of all the≈øe‚ñ™ (If a Quadrant be de≈øcribed, and upon the two Radiu≈øes two Tangents, and two or three Sines be erected (which in re≈øpect of other Arches will be co-Sines and co-Tangents) and two Secants drawn (which are likewi≈øe co-Secants) from the Center to the top of the Tangents) will appear by the fore≈øaid rea≈øons, out of my eleaventh Apodictick.

div.p: THe novelty of the≈øe words I know will ≈øeeme ≈øtrange to ≈øome, and to the eares of illiterate hearers ≈øound like termes of Conjuration: yet ≈øeeing that ≈øince the very infancie of learning, ≈øuch inventions have beene made u≈øe of, and new words coyned, that the knowledge of ≈øeverall things repre≈øentatively confined within a narrow compa≈ø≈øe, might the more ea≈øily be retained in a memory ≈øu≈øceptible of their impre≈ø≈øion (as is apparent by the names of Barbara, Celarent, Darii, Ferio, and fifteen more Syllogi≈øtick Moods, and by tho≈øe likewi≈øe of Gammuth, A-re, B-mi, C-fa-uth, and ≈øeventeen other ≈øteps of Guidos Scale, which are univer≈øally received by men of under≈øtanding, and that have their ≈øpirits tuned to the harmony of rea≈øon) I know not why Logick and Mu≈øick ≈øhould be rather fitted with ≈øuch helps then Trigonometrie, which, for certitude of demon≈øtration, hath been held inferior to no ≈øcience, and for ≈øublimity and variety of object, is the prime≈øt of the Mathematicks. This is the cau≈øe why I framed the Tri≈ø≈øotetras, wherein the termes by me invented, without regard of the initiall letters of the words by them expre≈ø≈øed, are compo≈øed of ≈øuch as, joyned together, are of mo≈øt ea≈øie pronunciation; as the Tangent complement of a Subtendent is ≈øooner uttered by Mu then by T C S; and the Secant complement of the ≈øide required, by Ry, then (in the u≈øuall apocopating way) by the fir≈øt ≈øyllables or letters of Secant complement, ≈øide, and required; and con≈øidering that without opening of the mouth no word can be ≈øpoken, which overture is performed by the vowel, to all the ≈øides and Angles I de≈øigned vowels, that in the coale≈øcencie of ≈øyllables, Sines, Tangents, and Secants might the better con≈øound therewith.

div.head: The explanation of the Tri≈ø≈øotetras.
div.p: A. ≈øignifieth an Angle: Ab. in the Re≈øolvers ≈øignifieth ab≈øtraction, but in the Figures and Datoquaeres the Angle between: Ac. or Ak. the acute Angle. Ad. Addition. AE. the fir≈øt ba≈øe: Amb. or Am. an obtu≈øe Angle: As Angles in the plurall number. At. the double verticall, whether externall or internall. Au. the fir≈øt verticall Angle: Ay, the Angle adjoyning to the ≈øide required.
B. or Ba. the true ba≈øe: Bis the double of a thing.
Ca. the perpendicular: Cra. the concur≈øe of a given and required ≈øide: Cur. the concur≈øe of two given ≈øides.
D. the partiall or little rectangle or rectanglet. Da. the datas. Di. or Dif. the difference: Dir. the directories. D. q. Datoquaeres. Di≈ø≈ø. of unlike natures.
E. a ≈øide: Eb. the ≈øide between: Enod, enodandas: Ereled. turned into ≈øides: Es, ≈øides in the plurall number: Ei, the ≈øide conterminall with the Angle required: Eu, the ≈øecond verticall Angle.

F. the new ba≈øe, or angularie ba≈øe, it being an Angle converted into a ≈øide: Fig. figures: Fin. Re≈ø. finall re≈øolvers: For, or Fo, outwardly, often made u≈øe of in the Cathetothe≈øis: Fr. a ≈øubducting of a le≈ø≈øer from a greater, whether it be Side or Angle.
G. An Angle or Side given: Gre, or aggre, the ≈øumme or aggregat.
Hal, or Al, the halfe.

I. Vowel, an Angle required: I Con≈øonant, the addition of one thing to another u≈øed in the clau≈øuls of ≈øome of the finall Re≈øolvers. In, intus or inwardly, and ≈øometimes turned into. Iu, the ≈øegments of the ba≈øe, or the ≈øegmented ba≈øe.
K. The complement of an Angle to a Semicircle.
L. The Secant: Leg, one of the comprehending ≈øides of an Angle. This repre≈øentative is once only mentioned.
M. A Tangent complement.
N. A Sine complement.

O. An oppo≈øite Angle, or rather Cathetoppo≈øite: Ob. the next cathetoppo≈øite Angle, by ≈øome called the fir≈øt oppo≈øite: Op. the prime cathetoppo≈øite Angle, by ≈øome called the ≈øecond oppo≈øite Oph, the fir≈øt of the cooppo≈øite Angles: Orth, an acute Angle: Ops, the ≈øecond of the cooppo≈øits: Os, oppo≈øite Angles in the plurall number. Oe, the ≈øecond ba≈øe; Ou, the Angle oppo≈øite to the ba≈øe.

P. Oppo≈øite, whether Angle or ≈øide: Par. a parallelogram or oblong. Prae≈ø. prae≈øub≈øervient: Po≈ø≈øub. po≈ø≈øub≈øervient: Pro. proportionall: Prod. directly proportionall: Pror, reciprocally proportionall: Pow. the Square of a Line: Pran. praeno≈øcendas.
Q. Continued if need be. Quae≈ø. Quae≈øitas. Quae. Quaere, or Required.

R. The Secant complement, and ≈øometimes in the middle of the Cathetothe≈øis ≈øignifies required, as alwayes in the latter end of a finall re≈øolver it doth by way of empha≈øis, when it followes I. or Y. R. likewi≈øe in the Axiom of Ruler≈øt ≈øtands for Radius.
Ra. the Radius, and in the Scheme the middle angularie Radius.
S. The Sine, and in the clo≈øe of ≈øome Re≈øolvers, the Summe. Sim. of like affection or nature: Sub≈ø. Sub≈øervient.

T. The Tangent. To. the Radius or total Sine, but in the Diagram it is taken for the left angularie Radius: Tœâ. the right angularie Radius in the Scheme propo≈øed: Tol. the fir≈øt hypotenu≈øal Radius thereof. Tom. the ≈øecond hyp. Radius. Ton. the third hyp. Rad. Tor. the fourth hyp. Rad. Tolb. the ba≈øiradius on the left hand. Torb. the ba≈øiradius on the right. Tolp. the Cathetorabdos, or Radius on the left. Torp. the Cathetoradius on the right. Th. the correctangle.
U. The Subtendent ≈øide. V. con≈øonant, to avoid va≈øtne≈ø≈øe of gaping, expre≈ø≈øeth the ≈øame in ≈øeverall figures. Ur. the Subtendent required.
W. The ≈øecond Subtendent.
X. Adjacent or Conterminal.
Y. The ≈øide required.

Z. The difference of Segments, and is the ≈øame with di, or dif. Neverthele≈ø≈øe the Reader may be plea≈øed to ob≈øerve, that no Con≈øonants in the Figures or Moods are repre≈øentative ≈øave P. and B. and that only in a few; both the≈øe two and all the other Con≈øonants meerly ≈øerving to expre≈ø≈øe the order and ≈øeries of the Moods and Figures re≈øpectively among≈øt them≈øelves, and of their con≈øtitutive parts in regard of one another.

div.head: ANIMADVERSIONS.
div.p:
IN the letter T. I have been ≈øomething large in the enumeration of ≈øeverall Radiu≈øes; for there being eleven made u≈øe of in the grand Scheme, whereof eight are Circumferentiall, and three Angularie, that they might be the better di≈øtingui≈øhed
from one another, when falling in proportion we ≈øhould have occa≈øion to expre≈ø≈øe them; I thought good to allot to every one of them its owne peculiar Character: all which I have done with the more exactne≈ø≈øe, that by the variety of the Radiu≈øes among≈øt them≈øelves, when any one of them in particular is pitched upon, we may the ≈øooner know what part of the Diagram, by meanes thereof, is fitte≈øt for the re≈øolving of any Orthogono≈øphericall problem: though indeed, I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, when ≈øometimes to a que≈øtion propounded, I adapt a figure apart, I doe indifferently (excluding all other characters) make u≈øe of To, or Rad, or R onely for the totall Sine, which, without any ob≈øcurity or confu≈øion at all, I have practi≈øed for brevities ≈øake.

Likewi≈øe, it being my maine de≈øigne in the framing of this Table, to make alcapable trigonometrically-affected Students with much facility and litle labour attaine to the whole knowledge of the noble Science of the doctrine of Triangles, I deemed it expedient, the more firmely and readily to imprint the ≈øeverall Datoquaeres or prae≈øcinded Problems thereof in their memories, to accommodate them accordingly with letters proper for the purpo≈øe; which, if the ingenious Reader will be plea≈øed to con≈øider, he will find, by the very letters them≈øelves, the place and number of each Datoquaere: This is the rea≈øon why my Tri≈ø≈øotetras (conforme to the Etymologie of its name) is in ≈øo many divers Ternaries, and Quaternaries divided; and that the ≈øharp, meane, blunt, double, and Liquid Con≈øonants of the Greek Alphabet, are ≈øo orderly be≈øtowed in their ≈øeverall roomes, being all and every one of them ≈øeated according to the nature of the Moods and Figures, who≈øe characteri≈øticks they are.

Thirdly, the Moods of the Planotriangular Table, being in all thirteene, whereof there be ≈øeven Rectangular, and ≈øix Obliquangular, are fitly comprehended by the three blunt, three meane, three ≈øharp, and ≈øoure double Con≈øonants, the Hebrew Shin being accounted for one of them.

Fourthly, the ≈øixteen Moods of the Orthogono≈øphericall Tri≈ø≈øotetras are contained under three ≈øharp, three mean, three blunt, three double, and foure Liquids, which foure doe orderly particulari≈øe the Binaries of the la≈øt two Figures.

Fifthly, the foure Monurgetick Loxogono≈øphericals are deciphred
by each its owne Liquid in front, according to their literall order.

Sixthly, the eight Loxogono≈øphericall Di≈øergeticks are al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed by the foure Liquids, but with this difference from the Monurgeticks, that the Vowels of A and E precede them in the fir≈øt ≈øyllable, importing thereby the Datas of an Angle or a Side. Now becau≈øe the≈øe Di≈øergeticks are eight in all, there being allotted to every Liquid that characteri≈øeth the Figures, the better to diver≈øifie the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Datas of each re≈øpective binarie from one another, (in ≈øo farre as they have reference to each its own Quae≈øitum) the Figurative Liquid is doubled when a Side is required, and remaineth ≈øingle when an Angle.

Furthermore, in the Oblique Sphericodi≈øergeticks, ≈øo farre as the ≈øen≈øe of the Re≈øolvers could beare it, I did trinifie them with letters convenient for the purpo≈øe, according to the ≈øeverall ca≈øes of their Datoquaeres, who≈øe diver≈øity reacheth not above the extent of œÄ. Œ≤. œÜ. and œÑ. Œ¥. Œ∏.

I had almo≈øt omitted to tell you, that for the more variety in the la≈øt two Figures of the Orthogono≈øphericals are ≈øet downe the two letters of Ch. and Shin, the fir≈øt a Spani≈øh, and the ≈øecond an Hebrew letter. Now if to tho≈øe helps for the memorie which in this Table I have afforded the Reader, both by the Alphabetical order of ≈øome Con≈øonants, and homogeneity of others in their affections of ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe, meanne≈ø≈øe, obtu≈øity, and duplicity, he joyne that artificiall aid in having every part of th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Chem ‚Ä¢ locally in his mind (of all wayes both for facility in remembring, and ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈ø≈øe of retention, without doubt, the mo≈øt expedite) or otherwi≈øe place the repre≈øentatives of words, according to the method of the Art of memory, in the ≈øeverall corners of a hou≈øe (which, in regard of their paucity are containable within a Parlour or dining roome at mo≈øt) he may with ea≈øe get them all by heart in le≈ø≈øe then the ≈øpace of an houre: which is no great expence of time, though be≈øtowed on matters of meaner con≈øequence.

div.head: The Commentary.
div.p: THe Axiomes of plain Triangles are foure, viz. Rulerst, Epro≈øo, Grediftal, and Bagrediffus.

Ruler≈øt, that is to ≈øay, the Subtendent in plain Triangles may be either Radius or Secant, and the Ambients either Radius, Sines, or Tangents; for it is a maxime in Planangular Triangles, that any ≈øide may be put for Radius, grounded on this, that from any point at any di≈øtance a Circle may be de≈øcribed: therefore if any of the ≈øides of a plain Triangle be given together with the Angler, each of the other two ≈øides is given by a threefold proportion, that is, whether you put that, or this, or the third ≈øide for the Radius; which difference occa≈øioneth both in plaine and Sphericall Triangles great variety in their calculations.
The Branches of this Axiom are Vrade≈ø≈øo and Eradetul.

Vrade≈ø≈øo, that is when the Hypotenu≈øa is Radius, the ≈øides are Sines of their oppo≈øit Angles; ≈øo that there be two Arches de≈øcribed with that Hypotenu≈øal identity of di≈øtance, who≈øe Centers are in the two extremities of the Subtendent; for ≈øo the ca≈øe will be made plaine in both the Legs, which otherwi≈øe would not appeare but in one.

Eradetul, when any of the ≈øides is Radius, the other of them is a Tangent, and the Subtendent a Secant. The rea≈øon of this is found in the very definitions of the Sines, Tangents, and Secants, to the which, if the Reader plea≈øe, he may have recour≈øe; for I have ≈øet them downe among≈øt my Definitions. Hence it is (according to Mr. Speidels ob≈øervation in his book of Sphericals) that the Sine of any Arch being Radius, that which was the totall Sine becomes the Secant complement of the ≈øaid Arch, and that the Tangent of any Arch being Radius, what was Radius becomes Tangent complement of that Arch.

The Directory of this Axiome is Vphech ‚Ä¢ t. which ≈øheweth us, that there be three Planorectangular Enodandas belonging thereto, viz. Vphener, Echemun, and Etenar; as for P≈øerelema, which is the Loxogonian one pointed at in my Tri≈ø≈øotetras, becau≈øe it is but a partiall Enodandum, I have purpo≈øely omitted to mention it in the Directory of Eradetul.

The ≈øecond Axiome is Epro≈ø ‚Ä¢ , that is, the ≈øides are proportionall to one another as the Sines of their oppo≈øite Angles; for ≈øeeing
about any Triangle a Circle may be circum≈øcribed, in which ca≈øe each ≈øide is a cord or Subten≈øe, the halfe whereof is the Sine of its oppo≈øite Angle, and there being alwayes the ≈øame rea≈øon of the whole to the whole, as of the halfe to the halfe, the ≈øides mu≈øt needs be proportionall to one another, as the Sines of their oppo≈øite Angles, quod probandum erat.

The Directory of this ≈øecond Axiome is Pubkegdaxe≈øh, which declareth that there are ≈øeven Enodandas grounded on it, to wit, foure Rectangular, Upalem, Ubeman, Ekarul, Egalem, and three Obliquangular, Danarele, Xemenoro, and Shenerolem.

The third Axiom is Grediftal, that is, in all plain Triangles, As the ≈øumme of the two ≈øides is to their difference, ≈øo is the Tangent of the halfe ≈øum of the oppo≈øite Angles to the Tangent of half their difference; for if a Line be drawne equall to the ≈øumme of the two ≈øides, and if on the point of Exten≈øion with the di≈øtance of the ≈øhorter ≈øide a Semicircle be de≈øcribed, and that from the extremity of the protracted Line a Diameter be drawne thorough the Circle where it toucheth the top of the Triangle in que≈øtion, till it occurre with a parallel to the third ≈øide, there will ari≈øe two Equicrurall Triangles, one whereof having one Angle common with the Triangle propo≈øed, and the three of the one being equall to the three of the other, any one of the equall Angles in the fore≈øaid I≈øo≈øceles mu≈øt needs be the one halfe of the two unknowne Angles. This is the fir≈øt ≈øtep to the obtaining of what we demand. Then do we find that the third ≈øide cutteth the ≈øides of the greate≈øt Triangle according to the Analogie required, which is perceivable enough, if with the di≈øtance of the outmo≈øt Parallel from the lower end thereof as Center, be de≈øcribed a new Circle; for then will the Tangents be per≈øpicuous and ≈øo much the more for their Rectangularity, the one with the Radius, and the other with its Parallel, which, being touched at an Angle de≈øcribed in a Semicircle, confirmeth the Rectangularity of both. By the Parallels likewi≈øe is inferred the equality of the alternate Angles, who≈øe addition and ≈øubduction to and from halfe the ≈øum of the two unknown Angles make up both the greater and le≈ø≈øer Angle. Hereby it is evident how the ≈øum of the two ≈øides, &c. which was to be proved.
The Directory of this third Axiom is Œ∏. onely; for it hath no Enodandum but Therelabmo.

The fourth Axiom is Bagrediffiu, that is, As the Ba≈øe or greate≈øt ≈øide is to the ≈øumme of the other ≈øides, ≈øo the difference of the other ≈øides to the difference of the Segments of the Ba≈øe; for if upon the Center of the verticall Angle with the di≈øtance of the ≈øhorte≈øt ≈øide be de≈øcribed a Circle, it will ≈øo cut the two greater ≈øides of the given Triangle, that, finding thereby two Oblongs of the nature of tho≈øe who≈øe equality is demon≈øtrated in my Apodicticks, we may inferre (the Oblong made of the ≈øumme of the ≈øides, and difference of the ≈øides being equall to the Oblong made of the Ba≈øe, and the difference of its Segments) that their ≈øides are reciprocally proportionall; that is, As the greate≈øt ≈øide is to the ≈øum of the other ≈øides: ≈øo the difference of the other ≈øides, to the difference of the Segments of the Ba≈øe, or greater ≈øide.
The Directory of this Axiom is Œ∏. and its onely Enodandum, (though but a partiall one) P≈øerelema.

div.head: The Planorectangular Table hath foure Figures.
div.p: IT is to be ob≈øerved, that Figure here is not taken Geometrically, but in the ≈øen≈øe that it is u≈øed in the Logicks, when a Syllogi≈øm is ≈øaid to be in the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, or third Figure; for, as there by the various application of the Medium or mean terme the Figures are con≈øtituted diver≈øe: ≈øo doth the difference of the Datas in a Triangle di≈øtingui≈øh the≈øe Tri≈ø≈øotetrall Figures from one another, and (to continue yet further in the Syllogi≈øticall Analogy) are according to the ≈øeverall demands (when the Datas are the ≈øame) ≈øubdivided into Moods.

The fir≈øt two vowels give notice of the Data's, and the third of what is demanded, ≈øo that Uale (and euphonetically pronounced ∆≤ale) which is the fir≈øt Figure, ≈øhewes that the Subtendent, and one Angle are given, and that one of the containing ≈øides is required. Vemane is the ≈øecond Figure, which pointeth out all tho≈øe problems wherein the Hypotenu≈øa, and one Leg are given, and an Angle, or the other Leg is required.

The third Figure is Enave, which comprehendeth all the Problems,
wherein one of the Ambients is given with an Oblique Angle, and the Subtendent, or other Ambient required.
The fourth and la≈øt of the Rectangular Figures is Ereva, which ≈øtandeth for tho≈øe Datoquaeres, wherein the including Sides are given, and the Subtendent or an Angle demanded.

div.head: Now let us come to the Moods of tho≈øe Figures.
div.p: THe fir≈øt Figure Vale hath but one Mood, and therefore of as great extent as it ≈øelfe, which is Upalem; who≈øe nature is to let us know, when a plane right angled Triangle is given us to re≈øolve, who≈øe Subtendent and one of the Obliques is propo≈øed, and one of the Ambients required, that we mu≈øt have recour≈øe unto its Re≈øolver, which being Rad‚ÄîU‚ÄîSapy‚òûYr ≈øheweth, that if we joyne the artificiall Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide demanded with the Logarithm of the Subtendent, the ≈øumme ≈øearched in the Canon of ab≈øolute numbers will afford us the Logarithm of the ≈øide required. The rea≈øon hereof is found in the ≈øecond Axiom, the fir≈øt Con≈øonant of who≈øe Directory evidenceth that Upalem is Epro≈øos Enodandum; for it is, As the totall Sine, to the Hypotenu≈øa: ≈øo the Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide required, is to the ≈øaid required ≈øide, according to the nature of the fore≈øaid Axiom, whereupon it is grounded.

The ≈øecond Figure Vemane hath two Moods, Ubeman and Uphener; the fir≈øt whereof comprehendeth all tho≈øe que≈øtions, wherein the Subtendent and an Ambient being given, an Oblique is required, and by its Re≈øolver V‚ÄîRad‚ÄîEg ‚òû So. thus ≈øatisfieth our demand, that if we ≈øubtract the Logarithm of the Subtendent from the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the middle termes, we have the Logarithm of the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle we ≈øeek for; for it is, As the Subtendent to the totall Sine, ≈øo the containing ≈øide given to the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle required. The rea≈øon likewi≈øe of this Analogy is found in the ≈øecond Axiom Epro≈øo, upon the which this Mood is grounded, as the ≈øecond Con≈øonant of its Directory giveth us to under≈øtand.

The ≈øecond Mood or Datoquaere of this Figure is Uphener, which ≈øheweth that tho≈øe que≈øtions in plaine Triangles,
wherein the Hypotenu≈øa and a Leg being given, the other Leg is demanded, are to be calculated by its Re≈øolver, which (becau≈øe the Canon of Logarithms cannot performe it at one operation, there being a nece≈ø≈øity to find one of the oblique Angles before the fourth terme can be brought into an Analogie) alloweth two Sub≈øervients for the atchievement thereof, viz. Vbeman, the fir≈øt Mood of the ≈øecond Figure, for the finding out of the Angle, and here (becau≈øe anterior in the work) called Prae≈øub≈øervient: then Vpalem, the fir≈øt Mood of all, for finding out of the Leg inquired, and here called Po≈ø≈øub≈øervient, becau≈øe of its po≈øteriority in the operation: yet were it not for the facility which addition and ≈øubtraction only afford us in this manner of calculation, we might doe it with one work alone by the Bucarnon or Pythagora≈øes Diodot, which plainly ≈øheweth us, that by ≈øubducing the ≈øquare of the Leg given, from the ≈øquare of the SubteÃÑdent, we have for the remainder another ≈øquare, who≈øe root is the ≈øide required. The rea≈øon of this is in my Apodicticks: but that of the former Re≈øolver by two operations, is in the fir≈øt Axiom, as by the fir≈øt ≈øyllable of its Directory is manife≈øt.

The third Figure is Enave, which hath two Moods, Ekarul and Egalem. The fir≈øt comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein one of the including ≈øides, and an Angle being given, the Subtendent is required, and by its Re≈øolver Sapeg‚ÄîEg‚ÄîRad ‚òû ∆≤r, ≈øheweth, that if we ≈øubtract the Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the given ≈øide from the ≈øumme of the middle termes (I meane the Logarithms of the one and the other) which are the totall Sine, and the Leg propo≈øed, we ≈øhall have the Hypotenu≈øa required; for it is, As the Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide given, to the fore≈øaid given ≈øide: ≈øo the totall Sine, to the Subtendent required. The rea≈øon of this proportion is grounded on the ≈øecond Axiom Epro≈øo; for K. the third Con≈øonant of its Directory, giveth us to under≈øtand, that it is one of the Enodandas thereof.

The ≈øecond Mood of Enave is Egalem, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein one of the Ambients, and an oblique Angle being given, the other Ambient is required: and by its Re≈øolver Rad‚ÄîTaxeg‚ÄîEg ‚òû Yr ≈øheweth, that if we adde the Logarithm of the ≈øide given to the Logarithm of the Tangent of the Angle conterminall with that ≈øide, and from the ≈øumme if we cut off the first digit on the left hand (which is equivalent to the ≈øubtracting
of the Radius whether double or ≈øingle) The remainder will afford us a Logarithm (≈øo neare as the irrationality of the termes will admit) in the Table of equall parts, expre≈ø≈øive of the ≈øide required; for it is As the whole Sine to the Tangent of an Angle in≈øident on the given ≈øide: ≈øo the ≈øide propo≈øed, to the ≈øide required: The rea≈øon hereof is grounded on the ≈øecond Axiom, for the fourth Con≈øonant of its Directory ≈øheweth, that Egalem is Epro≈øos enodandum.
The fourth Figure is Ereva, who≈øe Moods are Echemun and Etenar.

The fir≈øt, viz. Echemun, comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the two Ambients being given, the Subtendent is required, and (not being Logarithmically re≈øolvable in le≈ø≈øe then two operations) hath for its Prae and Po≈ø≈øub≈øervients the Moods of Etenar and Ekarul; for an Oblique Angle by this Method is to be ≈øearched before the Subtendent can be found out, and by rea≈øon of the≈øe ≈øeverall work ‚Ä¢ , this Mood is grounded on the two fir≈øt Axioms, and is an Enodandum partially depending on Eradetul, and Epro≈øo. Yet, if you will be plea≈øed to be at the paines of extracting the Square root, you may have the Subtendent at one work by a Quadrobiquadraequation as the Bucarnon doth in≈øtruct us, who≈øe demon≈øtration you have plainly ≈øet downe in the fourteenth of my Apodicticks.

The ≈øecond Mood of this Figure is Etenar, which includeth all tho≈øe que≈øtions wherein the two containing Sides being given, one of the Obliques is required, and by its Re≈øolver E‚ÄîGe‚ÄîRad‚òû Toge manife≈øteth, that, if from the Summe of the Radius and Logarithm of the ≈øide given, we ≈øubtract the Logarithm of the other propo≈øed ≈øide, the remainder will afford the Tangent of the Angle oppo≈øite to one of the given ≈øides, the Complement of which Angle to a right one is alwayes the mea≈øure of the other Angle, by the fifth of my Apodicticks; for it is, As the one Ambient is to the other Ambient, ≈øo the totall Sine to the Tangent of an Angle; which found out, is either the Angle required, or the Complement thereof to a right Angle. The rea≈øon of this Analogie is grounded on the ≈øecond Branch of the fir≈øt Axiom, as by the Characteri≈øtick of the Directory is perceivable enough to any indu≈øtrious Reader.

div.head: Of the Planobliquangular Triangles there be foure Figures: Alaheme, Emenarole, Enerolome, and Erelea,
div.p: THe fir≈øt and la≈øt of the≈øe foure are Monotropall Figures, and have but each one Mood: but the other two have a couple a piece, ≈øo that for the Planobliquangulars, all the foure together afford us ≈øix Datoquaeres.

The Mood of Alaheme is Danarele, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein two Angles being given and a Side, another Side is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver Sapeg‚ÄîEg‚ÄîSapyr‚òû Yr, ≈øheweth, that, if to the ≈øumme of the Logarithm of the ≈øide given, and of the Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide required, we adde the difference of the Secant complement from the Radius, (by ≈øome called the Arithmeticall complement of the Sine, and in Ma≈øter Speidels Logarithmicall Canon of Sines, Tangents, and Secants with good rea≈øon termed the Secant; for, though it doe not cut any Arch, thereby more Etymologically to de≈øerve the name of Secant, yet worketh it the ≈øame effect that the prolonged Radius doth) the operation will proceed ≈øo neatly, that if from the≈øe three Logarithms thus ≈øummed up, we onely cut off a Digit at the left hand, we will find as much by addition alone performed in this ca≈øe, as if from the propo≈øed ≈øumme the Sine of the Angle had beene ab≈øtracted; for the totall Sine thus unradiu≈øed is the Logarithm of the ≈øide required. But ≈øuch as are not acquainted with this compendious manner of calculating, or peradventure are not accommodated with a convenient Canon for the purpo≈øe, may, in Gods name, u≈øe their owne way, the Re≈øolver being of ≈øuch amplitude, that it extends it ≈øelfe to all ≈øorts of operations, whereby the truth of the fourth Ternary in this Mood may be attaind unto; for it is Analogi≈øed thus, As the Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide given is to the ≈øame given ≈øide; ≈øo the Sine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide required, to the required ≈øide. The rea≈øon of this proportion is grounded on the ≈øecond Axiom, the fir≈øt determinater of who≈øe Directory ≈øheweth, that Danarele is one of Epro≈øos Enodandas.
The ≈øecond Figure of the Planobliquangulars is Emenarole, who≈øe Moods are Therelabmo and Zelemabne.

The fir≈øt comprehendeth all tho≈øe Planobliquangular Problems wherein two ≈øides being given with an interjacent Angle, an oppo≈øite Angle is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver Aggres‚ÄîZes‚ÄîTalfagros ‚òû Talzos, ≈øheweth, that if from the ≈øumme of the Logarithm of the difference of the ≈øides, and Tangent of halfe the ≈øumme of the oppo≈øite Angles, be ≈øubduced the aggregat or ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the two propo≈øed ≈øides, the remainder thereof will prove the Logarithm of the Tangent of halfe the difference of the oppo≈øite Angles; the which joyned to the one, and ab≈øtracted from the other, affords us the mea≈øure of the Angle we require; for the Theoreme is, As the aggregat of the given ≈øides, to the difference of th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe ≈øides: So the Tangent of halfe the ≈øumme of the oppo≈øite Angles, to the Tangent of halfe the difference of tho≈øe Angles; which, without any more adoe, by ≈øimple Addition and Subtraction affordeth the Angle we demand. The third Axiom and the Theorem of the Re≈øolver of this Mood being but one and the ≈øame thing, I mu≈øt make bold to remit you to my Apodicticks for the rea≈øon of the Analogie thereof, the onely determinater of who≈øe Directory being Œ∏. pointeth out the Mood of Therelabmo for the ≈øole enodandum appropriated thereunto.

The ≈øecond Mood of this Figure is Zelemabue, which involveth all the Planobliquangulary Problemes, wherein two ≈øides being given with the Angle between, the third ≈øide is demanded: and not being calculable by the Logarithmicall Canon in le≈ø≈øe then two operations, becau≈øe it requireth the finding out of another Angle before it can fix upon the ≈øide, Therelabmo is allowed it for a Prae≈øub≈øervient, by vertue whereof an oppo≈øite Angle is obtained, and Danarele for its Po≈ø≈øub≈øervient and finall Re≈øolver, by who≈øe meanes we get the ≈øide required. The rea≈øon of the fir≈øt operation is grounded on the third Axiom, and of the ≈øecond operation on the ≈øecond: but becau≈øe this Mood is meerly a partiall Enodandum, neither of the fore≈øaid Axioms affordeth any Directory concerning it, otherwi≈øe then in the two Sub≈øervients thereof.

The third Figure is Eneroloms, who≈øe two Moods are X ‚Ä¢ monor ‚Ä¢
and Shenerolem.

The fir≈øt Mood of this Figure includeth all tho≈øe Planobliquangularie Problems, wherein two ≈øides being given, with an oppo≈øite Angle, another oppo≈øite Angle is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver
E‚ÄîSog‚ÄîGe‚òû So, ≈øheweth, that if from the aggregat of the Logarithm of one of the given ≈øides, and that of the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle propo≈øed, we ≈øubtract the Logarithm of the other given ≈øide, the re≈øidue will afford us the Logarithm of the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle required; for it is Analogi≈øed thus, As one of the ≈øides, to the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle given: ≈øo the other ≈øide propo≈øed, to the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle required. The rea≈øon of this proportion is from the ≈øecond Axiom, the ≈øixth characteri≈øtick of who≈øe Directory importeth, that Xemenoro is one of Epro≈øos enodandas.

The ≈øecond Mood of this Figure is Shenerolem, which containeth all tho≈øe Planobliquangularie Problems, wherein two ≈øides being given with an oppo≈øite Angle, the third ≈øide is demanded, which not being findable by the Logarithmicall Table upon the fore≈øaid Datas in le≈ø≈øe then two operations (becau≈øe an Angle mu≈øt be obtained fir≈øt before the ≈øide can be had) Xemenoro Prae≈øub≈øerves it for an Angle, and Danarele becomes its Po≈ø≈øub≈øervient for the ≈øide required. The rea≈øon of both the≈øe operations is founded on the ≈øecond Axiom, the la≈øt Characteri≈øtick of who≈øe Directory inrolleth Shenerolem for one of Epro≈øos enodandas.
The fourth figure is Erelea, which, being Monotropall, hath no Mood but P≈øerelema.

This P≈øerelema encompa≈ø≈øeth all tho≈øe Planobliquangulary Problems wherein the three ≈øides being propo≈øed, an Angle is required. This Datoquaere not being re≈øolvable by the Logarithms in le≈ø≈øe then two operations, becau≈øe the Segments of the Ba≈øe, or ≈øu≈øtaining ≈øide mu≈øt needs be found out, that by demitting of a Perpendicular from the top Angle, we may hit upon the Angle demanded: the Re≈øolver for the Segments is Ba‚ÄîGres‚ÄîZes‚òû Zius, whereby we learne, that if from the Logarithm of the ≈øumme of the ≈øides, joyned to the Logarithm of the difference of the ≈øides, we ≈øubtract the Logarithm of the Ba≈øe, the remainder is the Logarithm of the difference of the Segments, which difference being taken from the whole Ba≈øe, halfe the difference proves to be the le≈ø≈øer Segment. This Theorem being thus the Prae≈øub≈øervient of this Mood, its Po≈ø≈øub≈øervient is Vbeman, who≈øe generall Re≈øolver V‚ÄîRad‚ÄîEg‚òû Sor, is particulari≈øed for this ca≈øe Uxiug‚ÄîRad‚ÄîIng ‚òû Sor, which ≈øheweth, that if from the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the totall Sine, and of one of the Segments given, we ≈øubduce the Logarithm
of the Hypotenu≈øa conterminall with the Segment propo≈øed, the remainer will be the Logarithm of the Sine of the oppo≈øite Angle required; for the demitting of the Perpendicular opens a way to have the Theorem to be fir≈øt in generall propounded thus, As the Subtendent to the totall Sine, ≈øo the containing ≈øide given to the Sine of the Angle required: or in particular thus, As the Sine of the Co≈øubtendent adjoyning the Segment given is to the Radius, ≈øo is the ≈øaid Segment propo≈øed to the Sine of the Angle required.

div.head: Thus farre for the calculating of plaine Triangles, both right and oblique: now follow the Sphericals.
div.p: THere be three principall Axioms upon which dependeth the re≈øolving of Sphericall Triangles, to wit, Supro≈øca, Sbaprotca, and Sepro≈øo.

The fir≈øt Maxime or Axiom, Supro≈øca, ≈øheweth, that of ≈øeverall rectangled Sphericals, which have one and the ≈øame acute Angle at the Ba≈øe, the Sines of the Hypotenu≈øas are proportionall to the Sines of their Perpendiculars; for, from the ≈øame inclination every where of the one plaine to the other, there ari≈øeth an equiangularity in the two rectangles, out of which we may confidently inferre the homologall ≈øides (which are the Sines of the Subtendents, and of the Perpendiculars of the one, and the other) to be among≈øt them≈øelves proportionall. Its Directory is Uphugen, by the which we learn, that Uphanep, Ugemon, and Enarul, are its three enodandas.

The ≈øecond Axiom is Sbaprotca; whereby we learne, that in all rectangled Sphericals that have one and the ≈øame acute Angle at the Ba≈øe, the Sines of the Ba≈øes are proportionall to the Tangents of their Perpendiculars: which Analogie proceedeth from the equiangularity of ≈øuch rectangled Sphericals, by the ≈øemblable inclining of the plaine towards them both. This proportion neverthele≈ø≈øe will never hold betwixt the Sines of the Ba≈øes, and the Sines of their Perpendiculars; becau≈øe, if the Sines of the Ba≈øes were proportionall to the Sines of the Perpendiculars (the Sines
of the Perpendiculars being already demon≈øtrated proportionall to the Sines of the Subtendents) either the Sine of the Perpendicular, or the Sine of the Ba≈øe would be the cord of the ≈øame Arch, whereof it is a Sine; which is impo≈ø≈øible, by rea≈øon that nothing can be both a whole, and a part, in regard of one and the ≈øame thing; and therefore doe we onely ≈øay, that the Sines of the Ba≈øes, and Tangents of the Perpendiculars, and contrarily, are proportionall. Its Directory is Pubkutethep≈øaler, which ≈øheweth, that Upalam, Ubamen, ∆≤kelamb, Etalum, Ethaner, ep≈øoner, Alamun, and Erelam, are the eight Enodandas the reupon depending.

The third Axiom is, that the Sines of the ≈øides are proportionall to the Sines of their oppo≈øite Angles: the truth whereof holds in all Sphericall Triangles what≈øoever; which is proved partly out of the proportion betwixt the Sines of the Perpendiculars ≈øub≈øterned under equall Angles, and the Sines of the Hypotenu≈øas: and partly, by the Analogy, that is betwixt the Sines of the Angles ≈øu≈øtained by ≈øeverall Perpendiculars, demitted from one point, and the Sines of the Perpendiculars them≈øelves. The Directory of this Axiom is ∆≤chedezexam, whereby we know that Uchener, Edamon, Ezolum, Exoman, and Amaner, are the five Enodandas thereof.

div.head: The Orthogono≈øphericall Table con≈øi≈øteth of the≈øe ≈øix Figures: Valamenep, Vemanore, Enarulome, Erolumane, Achave, and E≈øheva.
div.p: THe fir≈øt Figure, Valamenep, comprehendeth all tho≈øe que≈øtions, wherein the Subtendent, and an Angle being given, either another Angle, or one of the Ambients is demanded.

Of this Figure there be three Moods, viz. Upalam, Ubamen, and Uphanep. The fir≈øt, to wit Upalam, containeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein the Subtendent and one oblique Angle being given, another oblique Angle is required, and by its Re≈øolver Torb‚ÄîTag‚ÄîNu ‚òû Mir, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Sine complement of the Subtendent ≈øide and Tangent of the Angle given, (the Logarithms of the≈øe are alwayes to be under≈øtood)
a digit being pre≈øcinded from the left, is equall to the Tangent complement of the Angle required; for the propo≈øition goeth thus, As the Radius, to the Tangent of the Angle given: ≈øo the Sine complement of the Subtendent ≈øide, to the Tangent complement of the Angle required: and becau≈øe Tangents, and Tangent complements are reciprocally proportionall, in≈øtead of To‚ÄîTag‚ÄîNu‚òûMir, or, To‚ÄîLu‚ÄîMag‚òûTir, which (for that the Radius is a meane proportionall betwixt the L. and N. the T. and M) is all one for inferring of the ≈øame fourth proportionall, or fore≈øaid quae≈øitum) we may ≈øay, Mag‚ÄîNu‚ÄîTo‚òûMir, that is, As the Tangent complement of the given Angle to the Co≈øine of the Subtendent, ≈øo the totall Sine to the Antitangent of the Angle demanded; for the totall Sine being, as I have told you, a meane proportionall betwixt the Tangents and Cotangents, the ≈øubtracting of the Cotangent, or Tangent complement from the ≈øumme of the Radius, and Anti≈øine re≈øiduats a Logarithm equall to that of the remainder, by ab≈øtracting the Radius from the ≈øum of the Co≈øine of the ≈øubtendent, and Tangent of the Angle given, either of which will fall out to be the Antitangent of the required Angle.

[Here alwayes is to be ob≈øerved, that the ≈øubtracting of Logarithms may be avoyded, by ≈øub≈øtituting the Arithmeticall complement thereof, to be added to the Logarithms of the two middle proportionals (which Arithmeticall complement (according to Gellibrand) is nothing el≈øe, but the difference between the Logarithm to be ≈øubtracted, and another con≈øi≈øting of an unit, or binarie with the addition of cyphers, that is the ≈øingle, or double Radius) for ≈øo the ≈øum of the three Logarithms, cutting off an unit, or binarie towards the left hand, will ≈øtill be the Logarithm of the fourth proportionall required.

For the greater ea≈øe therefore in Trigonometricall computations, ≈øuch a Logarithmicall Canon is to be wi≈øhed for, wherein the Radius is left out of all the Secants, and all the Tangents of Major Arches, according to the method pre≈øcribed by Mr. Speidel, who is willing to take the paines to make ≈øuch a new Canon, better then any that ever hitherto hath beene made u≈øe of, ≈øo that the publike, whom it mo≈øt concerneth, or ≈øome potent man, well minded towards the Mathematicks, would be ≈øo generous,
as to releeve him of the charge it mu≈øt needs co≈øt him; which, con≈øidering his great affection to, and ability in tho≈øe ≈øciences, will certainly be as ≈ømall a ≈øumme, as po≈ø≈øibly he can bring it to.]

p.hi: This Parenthe≈øis, though ≈øomewhat with the longest, will not (I hope) be di≈øplea≈øing to the ≈øtudious Reader.

div.p: The ≈øecond Mood of the fir≈øt Figure is Ubamen, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the Subtendent, and one oblique Angle being given, the Ambient adjoyning the Angle given is required, and by its Re≈øolver, Nag‚ÄîMu‚ÄîTorp‚òûMyr, ≈øheweth, that, if to the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the two middle proportionals, we adde the Arithmeticall complement of the fir≈øt, the cutting off the Index from the Aggregat of the three, will re≈øiduat the Tangent complement of the ≈øide required: and therefore with the totall Sine in the fir≈øt place, it may be thus propounded, Torp‚ÄîMu‚ÄîLag‚òûMyr; for the fir≈øt Theorem being, As the Sine complement of the Angle given, to the Tangent complement of the ≈øubtendent ≈øide: ≈øo the totall Sine, to the Tangent complement of the ≈øide required: ju≈øt ≈øo the ≈øecond Theorem, which is that refined, is, As the totall Sine, to the Tangent complement of the Subtendent: ≈øo the Secant of the given Angle, to the Tangent complement of the demanded ≈øide. Here you mu≈øt con≈øider, as I have told you already, that of the whole Secant I take but its exce≈ø≈øe above the Radius, as I doe of all Tangents above 45. Degrees; becau≈øe the cutting off the fir≈øt digit on the left, ≈øupplieth the ≈øubtraction, requi≈øite for the finding out of the fourth proportionall; ≈øo that by addition onely the whole operation may be performed, of all wayes the mo≈øt ≈øuccinct and ready. Otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe of the totall Sines meane proportionality betwixt the Sine complement, and the Secant; and betwixt the Tangent, and Tangent complement, it may be regulated thus, To‚ÄîTu‚ÄîNag‚òûTyr, that is, As the Radius, to the Tangent of the Subtendent, ≈øo the Sine complement of the Angle given, to the Tangent of the ≈øide required. The rea≈øon of the re≈øolution both of this, and of the former Datoquaere, is grounded on the ≈øecond Axiom, and the proportion that, in ≈øeverall rectangled Sphericals which have the ≈øame acute Angle at the Ba≈øe, is found betwixt the Sines of their Perpendiculars, and Tangents of their Ba≈øes, as is ≈øhewne you by the two fir≈øt Con≈øonants of the Directory of Sbaprotca.
