The third and la≈øt Mood of the fir≈øt Figure is Uphaner, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the Hypotenu≈øa, and one of the obliques being given, the oppo≈øite Ambient is required, and by its Re≈øolver Tol‚ÄîSag‚ÄîSu‚òûSyr, ≈øheweth, that, if we adde the Logarithms of the Sine of the Angle, and Sine of the Subtendent, cutting off the left Supernumerarie digit from the ≈øumme, it gives us the Logarithm of the Sine of the ≈øide demanded; for it is, As the totall Sine, to the Sine of the Angle given: ≈øo the Sine of the ≈øubtendent ≈øide, to the Sine of the ≈øide required: and becau≈øe by the Axiom of Ruler≈øt, it was proved, that when the Sine of any Arch is made Radius, what was then the totall Sine, becomes a Secant (and therefore Secant complement of that Arch) in≈øtead of Tol‚ÄîSag‚ÄîSu‚òûSyr, we may ≈øay, To‚ÄîRu‚ÄîRag‚òûRyr, that is, As the totall Sine, is to the Secant complement of the ≈øubtendent: ≈øo the Secant complement of the Angle given, to the Secant complement of the ≈øide demanded. The re≈øolution of this Datoquaere by Sines, is grounded on the fir≈øt Axiom of Sphericals, which elucidats the proportion betwixt the Sines of the Hypotenu≈øas, and Perpendiculars, as it is declared to us by the fir≈øt ≈øyllable of Supro≈øcas Directory.

The ≈øecond Figure is ∆≤emanore, which containeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall que≈øtions, wherein the ≈øubtendent, and an Ambient being propo≈øed, either of the obliques, or the other Ambient is required, and hath three Moods, viz. Ukelamb, Ugemon, and Uchener.

The fir≈øt Mood Ukelamb comprehendeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein the ≈øubtendent, and one including ≈øide being given, the interjacent Angle is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver Meg‚ÄîTorp‚ÄîMu‚òû Nir (or becau≈øe of the totall Sines mean proportion betwixt the Tangent, and Tangent complement) Torp-Teg‚ÄîMu‚òû Nir (which is the ≈øame in effect) ≈øheweth, that if from the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the middle termes, (which in the fir≈øt Analogy is the Radius, and Tangent complement of the ≈øubtendent) we ≈øubtract the Tangent complement of the given Ambient: or, in the ≈øecond order of proportionals, joyne the Tangent of the ≈øide given, to the Tangent complement of the ≈øubtendent, and from the ≈øum cut off the Index (if need be) both will tend to the ≈øame end, and produce for the fourth proportionall, the Sine complement of the Angle required; for to ≈øubtract a Tangent complement from the Radius, and another
number joyned together, whether that Tangent complement be more or le≈ø≈øe then the Radius, it is all one, as if you ≈øhould ≈øubtract the Radius from the ≈øaid Tangent complement, and that other number; becau≈øe the Tangent (or rather Logarithm of the Tangent; for ≈øo it mu≈øt be alwayes under≈øtood, and not onely in Tangents, but in Sines, Secants, Sides, and Angles, though for brevity ≈øake the word Logarithm be oftentimes omitted) becau≈øe I ≈øay, the Logarithms of the Tangent, and Tangent complement together, being the double of the Radius) if fir≈øt the Tangent complement ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe the Radius, and be to be ≈øubtracted from it, and another number, it is all one, as if from the ≈øaid number you would ab≈øtract the Radius, and the Tangent complements exce≈ø≈øe above it, ≈øo that the Radius being in both, there will remaine a Tangent with the other number-Likewi≈øe, if a Tangent complement, le≈ø≈øe then the Radius, be to be ≈øubtracted from the ≈øumme of the Radius, and another Logarithm; it is yet all one, as if you had ≈øubtracted the Radius from the ≈øame ≈øumme; becau≈øe, though that Tangent complement be le≈ø≈øe then the Radius: yet, that parcell of the Radius which was ab≈øtracted more then enough, is recompen≈øed in the Logarithm of the Tangent to be joyned with the other number; for, from which ≈øoever of the Tangents the Radius be ≈øubduced, its Antitangent is remainder: both which ca≈øes may be thus illu≈øtrated in numbers; and fir≈øt, where the Tangent complement is greater then the Radius, as in the≈øe numbers 6. 4. 3. 1. and 4. 2. 3. 1. where, let 6. be the Tangent complement, 4. the Radius, 3. the number to be joyned with the Radius, or either of the Tangents, and 1. the remainer; for 4. and 3. making 7. if you ab≈øtract 6. there will remaine 1. Likewi≈øe 2. and 3. making 5. if you ≈øubtract 4. there will remaine 1. Next, if the Tangent complement be le≈ø≈øe then the Radius, as in 2. 4. 3. 5. and 4. 6. 3. and 5. where, let 2. be the Tangent complement; for if from 4. and 3. joyned together, you ab≈øtract 2. there will remaine 5. which will al≈øo be the remainder, when you ≈øubtract 4. from 6. and 3. added together. Now to make the ≈øame Re≈øolver (the variety whereof I have beene ≈øo large in explaining) to runne altogether upon Tangents, in≈øtead of Meg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîMu‚òûNir, that is, As the Tangent complement of the ≈øide given, is to the totall Sine: ≈øo the Tangent
complement of the ≈øubtendent ≈øide, to the Sine complement of the Angle required, we may ≈øay, Tu‚ÄîTeg‚ÄîTo‚òûNir; that is, As the Tangent for the ≈øubtendent, is to the Tangent of the given ≈øide; ≈øo the totall Sine, to the Sine complement of the Angle required. All this is grounded on the ≈øecond Axiom Sbaprotca, and upon the reciprocall proportion of the Tangents and antitangents, as is evident by the third characteri≈øtick of its Directory.

The ≈øecond Mood of Vemanore is ∆≤gemon, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe orthogono≈øphericall problems, wherein the ≈øubtendent, with an Ambient being given, an oppo≈øite oblique is required, and by its Re≈øolver, Su-Seg-Tom‚òûSir, or (by putting the Radius in the fir≈øt place, according to Urade≈ø≈øo, the fir≈øt branch of the fir≈øt axiom of the Planorectangulars) To-Seg Ru‚òûSir, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the ≈øide given, and ≈øecant of the ≈øubtendent (the Supernumerarie digit being cut off) is the ≈øine of the Angle required; for the Theorem is, As the ≈øine of the ≈øubtendent, to the ≈øine of the ≈øide given: ≈øo the Radius, to the ≈øine of the Angle required: or, As the totall ≈øine, to the ≈øine of the ≈øide given: ≈øo the ≈øecant complement of the ≈øubtendent, to the ≈øine of the angle required: or, changing the ≈øines into ≈øecant complements, and the ≈øecant complements into ≈øines, we may ≈øay, To‚ÄîSu‚ÄîReg‚òûRir; becau≈øe, betwixt the ≈øine and ≈øecant complement, the Radius is a middle proportion. Other varieties of calculation in this, as well as other problems, may be u≈øed; for, be≈øides that every proportion of the Radius to the ≈øine, Tangent, or ≈øecant, and contrarily, may be varied three manner of wayes, by the fir≈øt Axiom of Plaine triangles, the alteration of the middle termes may breed ≈øome diver≈øity, by a permutat, or perturbed proportion, which I thought good to admoni≈øh the Reader of here, once for all, becau≈øe there is no problem, whether in Plaine, or Sphericall triangles, wherein the Analogie admitteth not of ≈øo much change. The rea≈øons of this Mood of Ugemon, depend on the Axiom of Supro≈øca, as the ≈øecond characteri≈øtick of ∆≤phugen ≈øeemeth to in≈øinuate.

The la≈øt Mood of the ≈øecond figure is ∆≤chener, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe problems, wherein the ≈øubtendent, & one Ambient being given, the other Ambient is Required, and by its Re≈øolver, Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, or, To‚Äîle-Nu‚òûNyr, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the ≈øine complement of the ≈øubtendent, and the ≈øecant of the
given ≈øide (which is the Arithmeticall complement of its Anti≈øine) giveth us the ≈øine complement of the ≈øide de≈øired, the Index being removed; for the theorem is, As the ≈øine complement of the given ≈øide, to the total ≈øine; ≈øo the ≈øine complement of the ≈øubtendent, to the ≈øine complement of the ≈øide required: or more refinedly, As the Radius, to the ≈øine complement of the ≈øubtendent: ≈øo the ≈øecant of the Leg given, to the ≈øine complement of the ≈øide required: and be≈øides other varieties of Analogie, according to the Axiom of Ruler≈øt, by making u≈øe of the reciprocall proportion of the ≈øine-complements with the ≈øecants we may ≈øay, To-Ne Lu-‚òûLyr, that is, As the totall ≈øine, is to the ≈øine complement of the given ≈øide: ≈øo the ≈øecant of the ≈øubtendent, to the ≈øecant of the ≈øide required. The rea≈øon of this Datoqueres Re≈øolution is in Sepro≈øo the third Axiom of the Sphericals, as is manife≈øt by the fir≈øt figurative of its Directorie Uchedezexam.
The third figure is Enarrulome, who≈øe three Moods are Etalum, Edamon, and Ethaner.

This figure comprehendeth all tho≈øe orthogono≈øphericall que≈øtions, wherein one of the Ambients with an Adjacent angle is given, and the ≈øubtendent, an oppo≈øite angle, or the other containing ≈øide is required.

Its fir≈øt Mood Etalum, involveth all tho≈øe Orthogono ≈øphericall problems, wherein a containing ≈øide, with an in≈øident angle thereon is propo≈øed, and the hypotenu≈øa demanded: and by its re≈øolver Torp-me-nag‚òûmur or (by inverting the demand upon the Scheme) Tolp.‚Äîme‚Äînag‚òûmur ≈øheweth, that the cutting of the fir≈øt left digit, from the ≈øumme of the Tangent complement of the Ambient propo≈øed, and the ≈øine complement of the given angle, affords us the Tangent complement of the ≈øubtendent required; for the theorem goes thus, As the totall ≈øine, to the tangent complement of the given ≈øide; ≈øo the ≈øine complement of the angle given, to the tangent complement of the hypotenu≈øa required. And becau≈øe the totall ≈øine, hath the ≈øame proportion to the tangent complement, which the ≈øine, hath to the ≈øine complement, we may as well ≈øay, To-meg-Sa‚òûnur, that is, As the Radius to the tangent complement of the Ambient ≈øide; ≈øo the ≈øine of the angle given, to the ≈øine complement of the ≈øubtendent required. The progre≈ø≈øe of this Mood, dependeth on the Axiom of Sbaprotca, as you may perceive by the fourth con≈øonant of its directorie Pubkutethep≈øaler.

The ≈øecond Mood of the third Figure, is Edamon, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein an Ambient and an Adjacent angle being given, the oppo≈øite oblique (viz. the angle under which the Ambient is ≈øubtended) is required, and by its Re≈øolver To-Neg-Sa‚òûNir, ≈øheweth that the Addition of the Co≈øine of the Ambient, and of the ≈øine of the Angle propo≈øed, affordeth us (if we omit not the u≈øuall pre≈øection) the Co≈øine of the Angle we ≈øeek for; for it is, As the Radius to the Co≈øine, or ≈øine complement of the given ≈øide: ≈øo the ≈øine of the Angle propo≈øed to the Anti≈øins or ≈øine complement of the Angle demanded: now the Radius being alwayes a meane proportionall betwixt the Sine complement, and the Secant, we may for To‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîSa‚òû Nir, ≈øay, To‚ÄîLeg‚ÄîRa ‚òû Lir, or To‚ÄîRag‚ÄîLe‚òûLir: that is, As the totall Sine to the Secant, or cutter of the ≈øide given, or to the Co≈øecant, or Secant complement of the given Angle; ≈øo is the Secant complement of the Angle, or Secant of the ≈øide, to the Secant, or cutter of the Angle required. The rea≈øon of all this is grounded on Sepro≈øo, becau≈øe it runneth upon the proportion betwixt the Sines of the ≈øides, and the Sines of their oppo≈øite Angles, as is per≈øpicuous to any by the ≈øecond ≈øyllable of the Directory of that Axiome.

The la≈øt Mood of the third Figure is Ethaner, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein an Ambient with an Oblique annexed thereto, is given, and the other Arch about the right Angle is required, and by its Re≈øolver, Torb‚ÄîTag‚ÄîSe ‚òû Tyr, ≈øheweth, that if we joyne the Logarithms of the two middle proportionals, which are the Tangent of the given Angle, and the Sine of the ≈øide, the u≈øuall prefection being ob≈øerved, we ≈øhall thereby have the Tangent, or toucher of the Ambient ≈øide de≈øired; for it is, As the Radius to the Tangent of the Angle given, ≈øo the Sine of the containing ≈øide propo≈øed to the ≈øide required: And becau≈øe the Tangent complement, and Tangent are reciprocally proportionall, the Sine likewi≈øe, and Secant complement, for To‚ÄîTag‚ÄîSe‚òûTyr, we may ≈øay, keeping the ≈øame proportion, To‚ÄîReg‚ÄîMa‚òûMyrs that is, As the Radius, to the Secant complement of the given ≈øide: ≈øo the Tangent complement of the Angle propo≈øed, to the Tangent complement of the ≈øide required. The truth of all the≈øe operations dependeth on Sbaprotca, the
≈øecond Axiome of the Sphericals, as is evidenced by Œ∏. the fifth characteri≈øtick of its Directory Pubkutethep≈øaler.

The fourth Figure is Erollumane, which includeth all Orthogono≈øphericall que≈øtions, wherein an Ambient, and an oppo≈øite oblique being given, the ≈øubtendent, the other oblique, or the other Ambient is demanded: It hath likewi≈øe, conforme to the three former Figures, three Moods belonging to it; the fir≈øt whereof is Ezolum.

This Ezolum comprehendeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall, Problems, wherein one of the Legs, with an oppo≈øite Angle being given, the Subtendent is required, and by its Re≈øolver, Sag‚ÄîSep‚ÄîRad‚òû Sur, or by putting the Radius in the fir≈øt place, To‚ÄîSe-Rag‚òû Sur, ≈øheweth, that the ab≈øtracting of the Radius from the ≈øum of the Sine of the ≈øide, and Secant complement of the Angle given, re≈øiduats the Sine of the hypotenu≈øa required; for it is, As the Sine of the Angle given, to the Sine of the oppo≈øite ≈øide: ≈øo the Radius to the Sine of the ≈øubtendent: or more refinedly, As the totall Sine, to the Sine of the ≈øide: ≈øo the Secant complement of the Angle given, to the Sine of the ≈øubtendent ≈øide: And becau≈øe of the Sines and Anti≈øecants, or Secant complements reciprocall proportionality, To‚ÄîSag‚ÄîRe‚òûRu, that is, As the Radius to the Sine of the Angle given: ≈øo the Secant complement of the propo≈øed ≈øide, to the Secant complement of the ≈øubtendent required. The rea≈øon of all this is grounded on the third Axiom Sepro≈øo, as is made manife≈øt by the third Syllable of its Directory.

The ≈øecond Mood of this Figure is Exoman, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein a containing ≈øide, and an oppo≈øite oblique being given, the adjacent oblique is required: and by its Re≈øolver, Ne‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNag‚òû Sir, or more refinedly, To‚ÄîLe‚ÄîNag‚òû Sir, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Sine of the Angle, together with the Arithmeticall complement of the Anti≈øine of the Leg, (which in the Table I have ≈øo much recommended unto the Reader, is ≈øet downe for a Secant) the u≈øuall prefection being ob≈øerved, affordeth us the Sine of the Angle required, and becau≈øe of the reciprocall proportion betwixt the Sine complement, and Secant; and betwixt the Sine, and Secant complement, the Theorem may be compo≈øed thus: To‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîLa‚òûRir, that is, As the Radius, to the Sine complement of the given ≈øide: ≈øo the Secant of the Angle propo≈øed, to the Secant complement of the
Angle demanded. The rea≈øon of this is likewi≈øe grounded on Sepro≈øo, as you may perceive by the fourth characteri≈øtick of its Directory.

The la≈øt Mood of this Figure is Ep≈øoner, which containeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein an Ambient and an oppo≈øite Oblique being given, the other Ambient is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver, Tag‚ÄîTolb‚ÄîTe‚òûSyr, or more elabouredly, Tolb‚ÄîMag‚ÄîTe‚òûSyr, ≈øheweth, that the prae≈øcinding of the Radius from the ≈øumme of the Tangent of the ≈øide, and Antitangent of the given Angle, re≈øiduats the Sine of the ≈øide required; for it is, As the Tangent of the Angle propo≈øed, to the totall Sine: ≈øo the Tangent of the given ≈øide, to the Sine of the ≈øide demanded: or, As the Radius, to the Tangent complement of the Angle given: ≈øo the Tangent of the given ≈øide, to the Sine of the ≈øide required: and becau≈øe of the reciprocall Analogy betwixt the Tangents, and Co-tangents: and betwixt the Sines, and Co-≈øecants, we may with the ≈øame confidence, as formerly, ≈øet it thus in the rule, To‚ÄîMeg‚ÄîTa‚òûRyr, and it will find out the ≈øame quae≈øitum. The rea≈øon of the operations of this Mood becau≈øe of the ingrediencie of Tangents dependeth on Sbaprotca, as is perceivable by the ≈øixth determinater of its Directory Pubkutethep≈øaler.

The fifth Figure of the Orthogono≈øphericals is Achave, which containeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the Angles being given, the ≈øubtendent or an Ambient is de≈øired, and hath two Moods Alamun, and Amaner.

Alamun comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the Angles being propo≈øed, the Hypotenu≈øa is required, and by its Re≈øolver Tag‚ÄîTorb‚ÄîMa‚òûNur, or more compendiou≈øly, Torb‚ÄîMag‚ÄîMa‚òûNur, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Co-tangents, not exceeding the places of the Radius, is the Sine complement of the ≈øubtendent required; for it is, As the Tangent of one of the Angles, to the Radius: ≈øo the Tangent complement of the other Angle, to the Sine complement of the Hypotenu≈øa demanded: or, As the totall Sine, to the Tangent complement of one of the Angles: ≈øo the Tangent complement of the other Angle, to the Sine complement of the ≈øubtendent we ≈øeek for. The running of this Mood upon Tangents, notifieth its dependance on Sbaprotca, as is evident by the ≈øeventh determinater of the Directory thereof.

The ≈øecond Mood of this Figure is Amaner, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Orthogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein the Angles being given, an Ambient is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver, Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîTœâ‚òûNyr, or more per≈øpicuou≈øly, Tœâ‚ÄîNoy‚ÄîRay‚òûNyr, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the Anti≈øine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide required, and the Arithmeticall complement of the Sine of the Angle, adjoyning the ≈øaid ≈øide, which we call its Secant complement, with the u≈øuall pre≈øection, is equall to the Sine complement of the ≈øame ≈øide demanded; for it is, As the Sine of the Angle adjoyning the ≈øide required, to the Anti≈øine of the other Angle: ≈øo the totall ≈øine, to the Anti≈øine of the ≈øide demanded: or, As the Radius, to the Anti≈øine of the Angle oppo≈øite to the demanded ≈øide: ≈øo the Anti≈øecant of the Angle conterminat with that ≈øide, to the Anti≈øine of the ≈øide required: and becau≈øe of the Analogy betwixt the Anti≈øines, and Secants: and likewi≈øe betwixt the Anti≈øecants, and Sines, we may expre≈ø≈øe it, To‚ÄîSay‚ÄîLa‚òûLyr; that is, As the Radius, to the Sine of the Angle in≈øident on the required ≈øide: ≈øo the Secant of the other given Angle, to the Secant of the ≈øide that is demanded. Here the Angulary intermixture of proportions giveth us to under≈øtand, that this Mood dependeth on Sepro≈øo, as is manife≈øted by the la≈øt characteri≈øtick of Uchedezexam the Directory of this Axiom.

The ≈øixth and la≈øt Figure is E≈øcheva, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the two containing ≈øides being given, either the ≈øubtendent, or an Angle is demanded: it hath two Moods, Enerul and Erelam.

The fir≈øt Mood thereof Enerul, containeth all ≈øuch Problems as having the Ambients given, require the ≈øubtendent, and by its Re≈øolver, Ton‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîNe‚òûNur, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the Co≈øines of the two Legs unradiated, is the Logarithm of the Co-≈øine of the ≈øubtendent; for it is, As the totall Sine, to the Co-≈øine of one of the Ambients: ≈øo the Co-≈øine of the other including Leg given, to the Co-≈øine of the required ≈øubtendent; and becau≈øe of the Co-≈øinal, and Secantine proportion, we may ≈øafely ≈øay, To‚ÄîLeg‚ÄîLe‚òûLur. That is, As the Radius to the Secant of one ≈øhanke or Leg: ≈øo the ≈øecant of the other ≈øhanke or Leg, to the ≈øecant of the Hypotenu≈øa demanded. The cour≈øing thus upon Sines, and their proportionals evidenceth that this Mood dependeth on Supro≈øca,
the fir≈øt of the Sphericall Axioms, which is pointed at by the third and la≈øt characteri≈øtick of ∆≤phugen the directorie thereof.

The ≈øecond Mood of the la≈øt figure, and con≈øequently the la≈øt Mood of al the Orthogono≈øphericals, is Erelam, which comprehendeth all tho≈øe orthogono≈øphericall problems, wherin the two containing ≈øides being propo≈øed, an Angle is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver, Sei‚ÄîTeg‚ÄîTorb‚òûTir, or by primifying the Radius, Torb‚ÄîTepi-Rexi‚òûTir, giveth us to under≈øtand, that the cutting off the Radius from the ≈øumme of the Tangent of the ≈øide oppo≈øite to the Angle demanded, and the co≈øecant of the ≈øide conterminat with the ≈øaid Angle, re≈øiduats the touch-line of the Angle in que≈øtion; for it is, As the ≈øine of the ≈øide adjoyning the Angle required, to the tangent of the other given ≈øide: ≈øo the Radius to the tangent of the Angle demanded: or, As the totall ≈øine to the Tangent of the Ambient oppo≈øite to the angle ≈øought: ≈øo the Anti≈øecant of the Leg adjacent to the ≈øaid asked Angle, to the Tangent or toucher thereof: and becau≈øe Sines have the ≈øame proportion to co≈øecants, which Tangents have to Cotangents, we may ≈øay, To‚ÄîSei‚Äîme‚òûmir, that is, As the Radius to the ≈øine of the ≈øide conterminat with the angle required: ≈øo the Cotangent of the other Leg, to the Cotangent of the Angle ≈øearched after: or yet more profoundly by an Alternat proportion, changing the relation of the fourth proportionall, although the ≈øame formerly required Angle, thus, To‚ÄîRei‚Äîme‚òûmor, that is, As the Radius to the Anti≈øecant of the ≈øide adjacent to the Angle ≈øought for, ≈øo the Antitangent of the other ≈øide, to the Antitangent of that ≈øides oppo≈øit Angle, which is the Angle demanded. The rea≈øon hereof is grounded on Sbaprotca; for the Tangentine proportion of the terms of this Mood ≈øpecifieth its dependance on the ≈øecond Axiom, which is ≈øhowen unto us by the eight and la≈øt characteri≈øtick of its directorie Pubkutethep≈øaler.

Here endeth the doctrine of the right-Angled ≈øphericalls, the whole diatypo≈øis wherof is in the Equi≈øolea or hippocrepidian diagram, who≈øe mo≈øt intricate amfractuo≈øities, renvoys, various mixture of analogies, and perturbat ≈øituation of proportionall termes, cannot choo≈øe but be pervious to the under≈øtanding of any judicious Reader that hath peru≈øed this Comment aright. And therefore let him give me leave (if he think fit) for his memorie ≈øake, to remit him to it, before he proceed any further.

div.head: The Loxogono≈øphericall Triangles, whether Amblygono≈øphericall or Oxygono≈øphericall, are either Monurgetick or Di≈øergetick.
THe Monurgetick have two figures, Datamista and Datapura.
div.p: Datami≈øta is of all tho≈øe Loxogono≈øpherical Monurgetick problems, wherein the Angles and ≈øides being intermixedly given, (and therefore one of them being alwaies of another kind from the other two) either an Angle, or a ≈øide is demanded: it hath two Moods, Lamaneprep, and Menerolo.

The fir≈øt Mood Lamaneprep, comprehendeth all tho≈øe Loxogono≈øphericall problems, wherein two angles being given, and an oppo≈øit ≈øide, another oppo≈øit ≈øide is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver, Sapeg‚ÄîSe‚ÄîSapy‚Äî‚òûSyr, ≈øheweth, that if to the Logarithms of the ≈øine of the ≈øide given, and ≈øine of the Angle oppo≈øit, to the ≈øide required, we joyne the Arithmeticall complement of the ≈øine of the Angle oppo≈øit, to the propo≈øed ≈øide (which is the refined Anti≈øecant) we will thereby attain to the knowledge of the ≈øine of the ≈øide demanded. The rea≈øon of this is grounded on the third Axiom, Sepro≈øa, as you may perceive by the fir≈øt ≈øyllable of the Obliquangularie directory, Lame.

The ≈øecond Mood of this figure is Menerolo, wich comprehendeth all tho≈øe Amblygono≈øphericall problems, wherein two ≈øides being given with an oppo≈øit angle, another oppo≈øit angle is demanded, and by its Re≈øolver Sepag‚ÄîSa‚ÄîSepi‚òûSir, ≈øheweth, that if to the ≈øumme of the Logarithms of the ≈øine of the given angle, and ≈øine of the ≈øide oppo≈øit to the angle required, we joyne the Arithmeticall complement of the ≈øine of the ≈øide oppo≈øit to the given angle (which is the refined Co≈øecant of the ≈øaid angle) it will afford us the ≈øine of the angle required. The rea≈øon of this operation is grounded on the third Axiom of Sphericalls, a progre≈ø≈øe in ≈øines ≈øhewing clearely, how that both this, and the former, doe totally depend on the Axiom of Sepro≈øa, as is evident by the ≈øecond ≈øyllable of its directorie, Lame.

The ≈øecond figure of the Monurgetick Loxogono≈øphericalls
treateth of all tho≈øe que≈øtions, wherein the Datas being either ≈øides alone, or Angles alone, an Angle or a ≈øide is demanded. This Figure of Datapura is divided into two Moods, viz. Nerelema, and Ralamane, which are of ≈øuch affinity, that upon one and the ≈øame Theorem dependeth the Analogy that re≈øolveth both.

The fir≈øt Mood thereof, Nerelema, comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein the three ≈øides being given, an Angle is demanded, and is the third of the Monurgeticks, as by its Characteri≈øtick the third Liquid is perceivable.

The curteous Reader may be plea≈øed to take notice, that in both the Moods of the Datapurall Figure, I am in ≈øome mea≈øure nece≈ø≈øitated for the better order ≈øake, to couch two precepts, or documents, for the Faciendas thereof, and to premi≈øe that one concerning the three Legs given, before I make any mention of the maine Re≈øolver, whereupon both the fore≈øaid Moods are founded, to which Re≈øolver, becau≈øe of both their dependences on it, I have allowed here in the Glo≈ø≈øe, the ≈øame middle place, which it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth in the Table of my Tri≈ø≈øotetras.

The precept of Nerelema is Halba≈øalzes * Ad* Ab* Sad≈øabreregalsbis Ir: that is to ≈øay, for the finding out of an Angle when the three Legs are given, as ≈øoone as we have con≈øtituted the ≈øu≈øtentative Leg of that Angle a Ba≈øe, the halfe thereof mu≈øt be taken, and to that halfe we mu≈øt adde halfe the difference of the other two Legs, and likewi≈øe from that halfe ≈øubtract the half difference of the fore≈øaid two Legs, then the ≈øumme and the re≈øidue being two Arches, we mu≈øt, to the Logarithms of the Sine of the ≈øumme, and Sine of the Remainer, joyne the Logarithms of the Arithmeticall complements of the Sines of the ≈øides, which are the refined Anti≈øecants of the ≈øaid Legs, and halfe that ≈øumme will afford, us the Logarithm of the Sine of an Arch, which doubled, is the verticall Angle, we demand; for out of its Re≈øolver, Par≈øes‚ÄîPowto‚ÄîPar≈øad≈øab‚òûPow≈øalvertir, is the Analogy of the former work made cleare, the Theorem being, As the Oblong or Parallelogram contained under the Sines of the Legs, to the ≈øquare, power or quadrat of the totall Sine: ≈øo the Rectangle, or Oblong made of the right Sines of the ≈øum, and difference of the halfe Ba≈øe, and difference of the Legs, to the ≈øquare of the right Sine of halfe the verticall Angle.

The rea≈øon hereof will be manife≈øt enough to the indu≈øtrious
Reader, if when by a peculiar Diagram, of who≈øe equiangular Triangles the fore≈øaid Sines and differences are made the con≈øtitutive ≈øides, he hath evinced their Analogy to one another, he be then plea≈øed to perpend, how, in two rowes of proportionall numbers, the products ari≈øing of the homologall roots, are in the ≈øame proportion among≈øt them≈øelves, that the ≈øaid roots towards one another are; wherewithall if he doe con≈øider, how the halfs mu≈øt needs keep the ≈øame proportion that their wholes; and then, in the work it ≈øelfe of collationing ≈øeverall orders of proportionall termes, both ≈øingle and compound, be carefull to da≈øh out a divider again≈øt a multiplyer, and afterwards proceed in all the re≈øt, according to the ordinary rules of Aequation, and Analogy, he cannot choo≈øe but extricat him≈øelfe with ea≈øe forth of all the windings of this elaboured propo≈øition.

Upon this Theorem (as I have told you) dependeth likewi≈øe the Document for the faciendum of Ralamane, which is the ≈øecond Mood of Datapura, and the la≈øt of the Monurgetick Loxogono≈øphericals, as is pointed at by Nera the Directory therof. This Mood Ralamane comprehendeth all tho≈øe Loxogono≈øphericall Problems, wherein the three Angles being given, a ≈øide is demanded. And by its Re≈øolver, Par≈øes‚ÄîPowto‚ÄîPar≈øad≈øab‚òûPow≈øalvertir, according to the peculiar precept of this Mood Kourbfa≈øines (Ereled) Koufbraxypopyx, ≈øheweth, that if we take the complement to a ≈øemicircle of the Angle oppo≈øite to the ≈øide required, which for di≈øtinction ≈øake we doe here call the Ba≈øe; and frame, of the fore≈øaid complement to a ≈øemicircle, a ≈øecond Ba≈øe for the fabrick of a new Triangle, who≈øe other two ≈øides have the graduall mea≈øure of the former Triangles other two Angles: (and ≈øo the three Angles being converted into ≈øides) the complement to a Semicircle of the new Verticall, or Angle oppo≈øite to the new Ba≈øe, will be the mea≈øure of the true Ba≈øe or Leg required, and the Angle in≈øident on the right end of the new Ba≈øe in the ≈øecond Triangle, falleth to be the ≈øide conterminall with the left end of the true Ba≈øe in the fir≈øt Triangle, and the Angle adjoyning the left end of the fal≈øe Ba≈øe in the ≈øecond Triangle, becomes the ≈øide adjacent to the right end of the old Ba≈øe in the fir≈øt Triangle. So that thus by the Angles all andeach of the ≈øides are found out, all which works are to be performed by the preceding
Mood, upon the Theorem, whereof the rea≈øon of all the≈øe operations doth depend.

div.head: The Di≈øergetick Loxogono≈øphericals are grounded on foure Axioms, viz.
div.p: 1. NAbadpro≈øver. 2. Naverprortes, Siubprortab, and Niubprodne≈øver: the foure Directories whereof, each in order to its owne Axiome, are Alama, Allera, Ammena, and Ennerra.

The fir≈øt Axiome is, Nabadpro≈øver, that is, In Obliquangular Sphericals, if a Perpendicular be demitted from the verticall Angle to the oppo≈øite ≈øide, continued if need be, The Sines complements of the Angles at the Ba≈øe, will be directly proportionall to the Sines of the verticall Angles, and contrary: the rea≈øon hereof is inferred out of the proportion, which the Sines of Angles, ≈øub≈øterned by Perpendiculars, have to the Sines of the ≈øaid perpendiculars, ≈øo that they belong to the Arches of great Circles, concurring in the ≈øame point, and that from ≈øome point of the one, they be let fall on the other Arches‚ñ™ which proportion of the Sines of the ≈øaid Perpendiculars, to the Sines of the Angles ≈øubtended by them, ≈øtoweth immediatly from the proportion, which (in ≈øeverall Orthogono≈øphericals, having the ≈øame acute Angle at the Ba≈øe) is betwixt the Sines of the Hypotenu≈øas, and the Sines of the perpendiculars; the demon≈øtration whereof is plainly ≈øet downe in my Glo≈ø≈øe on Supro≈øca, the fir≈øt generall Axiome of the Sphericals, of which this Axiome of Nabadpro≈øver is a con≈øectary.
The Directory of this Axiome is Alama, which ≈øheweth, that the Moods of Alamebna and Amanepra are grounded on it.

The ≈øecond Di≈øergetick Axiome is Naverprortes, that is to ≈øay, the Sines complements of the verticall Angles, in obliquangular Triangles (a Perpendicular being let fall from the double verticall on the oppo≈øite ≈øide) are reciprocally proportionall to the Tangents of the ≈øides: the rea≈øon hereof proceedeth from Sbaprotca, the ≈øecond generall Axiome of the Sphericals; according to which, if we doe but regulate, after the cu≈øtomary Analogicall manner, two quaternaries
of proportionals of the former Sines complements, and Tangents propo≈øed, we will find by the extremes alone (excluding all the intermediate termes) that the Sines complements of the verticall Angles (both forwardly, and inver≈øedly) are reciprocally proportioned to the Tangents of the ≈øides, and contrariwi≈øe from the Tangents, to the Sines. The Directory of this Axiome is Allera, which evidenceth, that the Moods of Allamebne, and Erelomab depend upon it.

The third Di≈øergetick Axiome is Sinbprortab, that is to ≈øay, that in Obliquangular Sphericals (if a perpendicular be drawne from the verticall Angle unto the oppo≈øite ≈øide, continued if need be) the Sines of the ≈øegments of the Ba≈øe, are reciprocally proportionall to the Tangents of the Angles conterminate at the Ba≈øe, and contrary: the proofe of this, as well as that of the former confectary dependeth on Sbaprotca, the ≈øecond generall Axiome of the Sphericals, according to which, if we ≈øo Diagrammati≈øe an Ambly gono≈øphericall Triangle, by Quadranting the Perpendicular, and all the ≈øides, and de≈øcribing from the Ba≈øangulary points two Quadrantall Arches, till we hit upon two rowes of proportionall Sines of Ba≈øes to Tangents of Perpendiculars, then ≈øhall we be ≈øure (if we exclude the intermediate termes) to fall upon a reciprocall Analogy of Sines, and Tangents, which alternatly changed, will afford the reciprocall proportion of the Sines of the Segments of the Ba≈øe, to the Tangents of the Angles conterminat thereat, the thing required.
The Directory of this Axiome is Ammena, which certifieth that Ammanepreb and Enerablo are founded thereon.

The fourth and la≈øt Di≈øergetick Axiome is Niubprodne≈øver, that is to ≈øay, that in all Loxogono≈øphericals (where the Cathetus is regularly demitted) the Sines complements of the Segments of the Ba≈øe, are directly proportionall to the Sines complements of the ≈øides of the verticall Angles, and contrary. The rea≈øon hereof is made manife≈øt, by the proportion that is betwixt the Sines of Angles, ≈øubtended by Perpendiculars and the Sines of the≈øe Perpendiculars; out of which we collation ≈øeverall proportions, till, both forwardly and inver≈øedly we pitch at la≈øt upon the direct proportion required.
The Directory of this Axiome is Ennerra, which declareth that Ennerable, and Errelome are its dependents.

div.head: Of the Di≈øergetick Loxogono≈øphericals there be in all foure Figures; two Angulary, and two Laterall.
div.p: THe two Angulary are Ahalebmane and Ahamepnare: The two laterall are Ehenabrole and Eheromabne.

The fir≈øt Angulary Di≈øergetick Loxogono≈øphericall Figure, Ahalebmane, comprehendeth all tho≈øe Problems, wherein two Angles being given with a ≈øide betweene, either the third Angle, or an oppo≈øite ≈øide is demanded; and accordingly hath two Moods, the fir≈øt whereof is Alamebna, and the ≈øecond Allamebne.

Alamebna concerneth all tho≈øe Loxogono≈øphericall Di≈øergetick Problems, wherein two Angles being propo≈øed, with an interjacent ≈øide, the third Angle is required; which Angle, according to the ≈øeverall Ca≈øes of this Mood, is alwayes one of the Angles at the Ba≈øe, that is to ≈øay (in the termes of my Tri≈ø≈øotetr as) a prime, or next oppo≈øite, or at lea≈øt one of the co-oppo≈øites, to the Perpendicular to be demitted. And therefore, conforme to the nature of the Ca≈øe of the Datoquaere in hand, and that it may the more conveniently fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of the Axiome of Nabadpro≈øver, an Angle by the fir≈øt operation of this Di≈øergetick is to be found out, which mu≈øt either be a double verticall, a verticall in the little rectangle, or a verticall, or co-verticall (as ≈øometimes I call it) in one of the correctangles.

Thus much I have thought fit to premi≈øe of the praeno≈øcendum of this Mood, before I come to its Cathetothe≈øis; becau≈øe, in my Tri≈ø≈øotetrall Table, to avoid the confu≈øion of homogeneall termes (though the order of doctrine would ≈øeeme to require another Method) the fir≈øt and prime Orthogono≈øphericall work is totally unfolded, before I ≈øpeak any thing of the variety of the Perpendiculars demi≈ø≈øion, to which, owing its rectangularity, it thereby obtaineth an infallible progre≈ø≈øe to the quae≈øitum: but, ≈øeeing in the Glo≈ø≈øe I am not to a≈øtrict my ≈øelf to ≈øo little bounds, as in my Table, I will ob≈øerve the order that is mo≈øt expedient; and, before the re≈øolution of any operation in this Mood, deduce the diver≈øity of the Perpendiculars pro≈øiliencie in the ≈øeverall Ca≈øes thereof.

Let the Reader then be plea≈øed to con≈øider, that the generall Maxim for the Cathetothe≈øis of this Mood is Cafregpiq, the meaning whereof is, that, whether the ≈øide whereon the Perpendicular is demitted be increa≈øed or not, that is to ≈øay, whether the Perpendicular fall outwardly, or inwardly, it mu≈øt fall from the extremity of the given ≈øide, and oppo≈øite to the Angle required: however it is to be remarked, that in this Mood, whatever be the affection of the Angles (unle≈ø≈øe they be all three alike) the Perpendicular may fall out wardly.
The generall maxim for the Cathetothe≈øis of this Mood, as well as for that of all the re≈øt, is divided into foure Tenets, according to the number of the Ca≈øes of every Mood.

Here mu≈øt I admoni≈øh the Reader, that he ≈øtartle not at the mentioning of foure e≈øpeciall Cathetothetick Tenets, and foure ≈øeverall Ca≈øes belonging to each Di≈øergetick Mood, ≈øeeing, to the mo≈øt ob≈øervant eye, there be but three of either perceptible in my Tri≈ø≈øotetr as; for, the fourth both Tenet and Ca≈øe being the ≈øame by way of expre≈ø≈øion in all the Moods, and being fully re≈øolved by the third Ca≈øe of every Mood, it ≈øhall ≈øuffice to ≈øpeak thereof here once for all: The Tenet of this common Ca≈øe is Simomatin, that is to ≈øay, when all the three Angles in any of tho≈øe Di≈øergeticks are of the ≈øame affection, either all acute, or all oblique, the Perpendicular falleth inwardly, whether the double verticall be an Angle given, an Angle demanded, or neither. Yet here it is to be con≈øidered, that ≈øeeing Triangles may be either calculated by their reall and naturall, or by their circular parts, or by both together, and that for the more facility we oftentimes, in≈øtead of the propo≈øed Triangle, re≈øolve its oppo≈øite; it is not the reall and given Triangle, that in this ca≈øe we ≈øo much take notice of, as of its re≈øolvable, and equivalent, the oppo≈øite Triangle: as for example, If a Sphericall Triangle, with two obtu≈øe Angles, and one acute, be given you to re≈øolve, it will fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of Simomatin; becau≈øe its oppo≈øite Sphericall is ≈øimply acute angled: and al≈øo if you be de≈øired to calculate a Sphericall Triangle with two acute Angles, and one obtu≈øe, it will likewi≈øe fall within the reach of the ≈øame Ca≈øe; becau≈øe its oppo≈øite Sphericall is ≈øimply obtu≈øangled. The rea≈øon of both the premi≈ø≈øes is from the equality of the oppo≈øite Angles of concurring Quadrants,
which that they are equall, no man needs to doubt, that will take the paines to let fall a Perpendicular from the middle of the one Quadrant upon the other; for ≈øo there will be two Triangles made equilaterall: and ≈øeeing it is an univer≈øally received truth, that equall ≈øides ≈øu≈øtaine equall Angles, the identitie of the Perpendicular in both the fore≈øaid Triangles, mu≈øt needs manife≈øt the equality of the two oppo≈øite Angles.

I have beene the ampler in the elucidating of this Ca≈øe, that, it over-running all the Moods of the Di≈øergetick Loxogono≈øphericals, the Reader, in what Mood or Datoquare ≈øoever he plea≈øe to re≈øolve this fore≈øaid Ca≈øe, may for that purpo≈øe to this place have recour≈øe; to the which, without any further intended reiteration of this Tenet, I doe heartily remit him.

The fir≈øt e≈øpeciall Tenet of the generall Maxim of the Cathetothe≈øis of this Mood is Da≈øimforaug, that is, When the given Angles are of the ≈øame nature, but different from the required, the Perpendicular falleth outwardly, and the fir≈øt verticall is a given Angle: the ≈øecond Tenet belonging to the ≈øecond Ca≈øe of this Mood is Dadi≈øforeug, that is, When the propo≈øed Angles are of different affections, the Perpendicular is externally demitted, and one of the given Angles is a ≈øecond verticall: Yet this di≈øcrepance is to be ob≈øerved betweene the externall pro≈øiliencie of the Perpendicular Arch in this Ca≈øe, and that other of the former; that in the former, it is no matter from which of the ends of the propo≈øed ≈øide, the Perpendicular be let fall upon one of the comprehending Legs of the Angle required, which Leg mu≈øt be increa≈øed; for it is a generall Notandum, that the ≈øu≈øtentative Leg of a perpendiculars exterior demi≈ø≈øion must alwayes be continued: but in this Ca≈øe, the outward falling of the Perpendicular is onely from one extremity of the given ≈øide; for, if it be demitted likewi≈øe from the other end, it falleth then inwardly, and ≈øo produceth the third Tenet of this Mood, which is Dadi≈øgatin, that is, If the given Angles be of a different quality, and that the Perpendicular be internally demitted, the double verticall is one of the propo≈øed Angles.

The nature of the Perpendiculars demi≈ø≈øion in all the Ca≈øes of this Mood being thus to the full explained, we may without impediment proceed to the performance of all the Orthogono≈øphericall operations, each in its owne order thereto belonging.

To begin therefore at the fir≈øt, who≈øe qua≈øitum (as I have told you already) is a verticall Angle, we mu≈øt know, ≈øeeing the work is Orthogono≈øpherically to be performed, that the forementioned praeno≈øcendum cannot be obtained without the help of one of the ≈øixteen Datoquaeres; and therefore in my Tri≈ø≈øotetras (con≈øidering the nature of what is given, and asked in the Ca≈øes of this Mood) I have appointed Upalam to be the ≈øub≈øervient of its praeno≈øcendum; for, by the Re≈øolver thereof, To‚ÄîTag‚ÄîNu‚òû Mir, (the ≈øubtendent and an Angle being given; for one of the given ≈øides of every Loxogono≈øphericall, if the Perpendicular be rightly demitted, becomes a ≈øubtendent, and ≈øometimes two given ≈øides are ≈øubtendents both) we frame the≈øe three peculiar Problems, for the three praeno≈øcendas; to wit, Utopat, for the double verticall, by the meanes of the great Subtendent ≈øide, and the prime oppo≈øite Angle: ≈øecondly, Udobaud, for obtaining of the fir≈øt verticall in the little rectangle, by vertue of the le≈ø≈øer ≈øubtendent in the ≈øame rectangle, and the next oppo≈øite Angle: la≈øtly, Uthophauth, for the first Co-verticall, by meanes of the fir≈øt Co-≈øubtendent, and fir≈øt cooppo≈øite Angle: all which is at large ≈øet downe in the fir≈øt partition of Alamebna in my Table.

The fir≈øt and chiefe operation being thus perfected, the verticall Angles ≈øo found out mu≈øt concurre with each its corre≈øpondent oppo≈øite for the obtaining of the Perpendicular, nece≈ø≈øary for the accompli≈øhment of the ≈øecond operation in every one of the Ca≈øes of the fore≈øaid Mood; to which effect Amaner is made the Sub≈øervient, by who≈øe Re≈øolver Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîTw‚òû Nyr, the≈øe three Datoquaeres, Opatca, Obautca, and Ophauthca come to light, and is manife≈øtly ≈øhown how, by any paire of three ≈øeverall couples of different Angles, the Perpendicular is acquirable.

Now, though of this work (as it is a ≈øingle one) no more then of the other ≈øucceeding it in the ≈øame Mood, nor of the la≈øt two in any of the Di≈øergeticks in their full Analogy, I doe not make any mention at all in my Table; but, after the couching of the fir≈øt operation for the Praeno≈øcendas, ≈øupply the roomes of the other two, with an equivalent row of proportionals out of them ≈øpecified, for attaining to the knowledge of the maine quae≈øitum: yet in this Comment upon that Table, for the more per≈øpicuities ≈øake, and that the Reader may as well know, what way the rule
is made, as how thereby a demand is to be found out, I have thought fit to expatiat my ≈øelfe for his ≈øatisfaction on each operation apart, and Analytically to di≈øplay in the glo≈ø≈øe, what is compounded in the Tri≈ø≈øotetras.

And therefore, according to that pre≈øcribed method, to proceed in this Mood, the perpendicular by the ≈øecond operation being already obtained, it is requi≈øite for the promoving of a third work, that the ≈øaid Perpendicular be made to joyne with the ≈øecond verticaline, the double verticall, and ≈øecond co-verticall conforme to the quality of the three Ca≈øes, thereby to obtaine the Angles at the Ba≈øe, for the which all the≈øe operations have beene ≈øet on foot; to wit, the next cathetoppo≈øite, (who≈øe complement to a Semicircle is alwayes the Angle required) the prime cathetoppo≈øite, and the ≈øecond Cocathetoppo≈øite: for the pro≈øecuting of this la≈øt work, Edoman is the ≈øub≈øervient, by who≈øe Re≈øolver, To‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîSa‚òûNir, we are in≈øtructed how to regulate the Problemets of Catheudob, Cathatop, and Catheuthops.

Now the≈øe two la≈øt operations being thus made patent in their ≈øeverall ≈øtructures, it is not ami≈ø≈øe that we ponder how appo≈øitely they may be conflated into one, to the end, that the verity of all the finall Re≈øolvers of the Di≈øergeticks in my Tri≈ø≈øotetras (which are all and each of them compo≈øed of the ingredient termes of two different works) may be the more evidently knowne, and obvious to the reach of any ordinary capacity, for the performance hereof, the Re≈øolvers of the≈øe two operations are to be laid before us, Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîTa‚òûNyr, and To‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîSa‚òûNir: and, ≈øeeing out of both the≈øe orders of proportionals, there mu≈øt re≈øult but one, it is to be con≈øidered, which be the foure ejectitious termes, and which tho≈øe foure we ≈øhould re≈øerve for the Analogy required; all which, that it may be the better under≈øtood by the indu≈øtrious Reader, I will interpret the Re≈øolvers ≈øo farre forth as is requi≈øite: and therefore Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîTo‚òûNyr, being, As the Sine of one of the Angles at the Ba≈øe, or Cathetoppo≈øite, is to the Sine complement of a verticall: ≈øo the Radius to the Sine complement of the Perpendicular: And the other, To‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîSa‚òûNir, being, As the Radius, to the Sine complement of the Perpendicular: ≈øo the Sine of a verticall, to the Sine complement of a Cathetoppo≈øite or Angle at the Ba≈øe; it is perceivable enough
how both the Radius, and the Perpendicular are in both the rows: nor can it well e≈øcape the knowledge of one never ≈øo little ver≈øed in the elements of Arithmetick, that the Perpendiculars being the fourth terme in the fir≈øt order of proportionals, is nothing el≈øe but that it is the quotient of the product of the middle termes, divided by the fir≈øt, or Logarithmically the remainder of the fir≈øt termes ab≈øtraction from the ≈øumme of the middle two; ≈øo that the whole power thereof is inclo≈øed in the≈øe three termes, whereby it is mo≈øt evident, that with what terme ≈øoever the fore≈øaid Perpendicular be employed to concurre in operation, the ≈øame effect will be produced by the concurrence of its ingredients with the ≈øaid terme, and therefore in the ≈øecond row of proportionals, where it is made u≈øe of for a fellow multiplyer with the third terme to produce a factus, which divided may quote the maine quae≈øitum, or Logarithmically to joyne with the third terme, for the ≈øumming of an Aggregat from which the fir≈øt terme being ab≈øtracted, may re≈øiduat the terme demanded, it is all one, whether the work be performed by it ≈øelfe, or by its equivalent, viz. the three fir≈øt termes of the fir≈øt order of proportionals, in who≈øe potentia it is: whereupon the fourth terme in the ≈øecond row being that, for the obtaining whereof, both the Analogies are made, we need not wa≈øte any labour about the finding out of the Perpendicular (though a ≈øub≈øervient to the chiefe quae≈øitum) but leaving roome for it in both the rows, that the equipollencie of its conflaters may the better appeare, go on in work without it, and, by the meanes of its con≈øtructive parts, with as much certainty effectuat the ≈øame de≈øigne.

Thus may you ≈øee then how the eight termes of the forementioned Re≈øolvers, are reduced unto ≈øix; but there remaining yet two more to be ejected, that both the orders may be brought unto a compound row of foure proportionals: let us con≈øider the Radius, which, being in both the rows as I have once told you already, may peradventure, without any prejudice to the work, be ≈øpared out of both. Thus much thereof to any is perceiveable, that in the fir≈øt Re≈øolver, it is the third proportionall; and in the ≈øecond, the fir≈øt, and con≈øequently a multiplyer in the one, and in the other a divider: or Logarithmically in the ≈øecond a ≈øubtractor, and in the fir≈øt an adder: now it being well known that divi≈øion overthrows
the ≈øtructure of multiplication, and that what is made up by addition, is by ≈øubtraction ca≈øt down; we need not undergoe the laboriou≈øne≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch a Penelopaean task, and by the divi≈øion and ab≈øtraction of what we did adde and multiply, weave and unweave, build up, and throw downe the ≈øelf ≈øame thing: but choo≈øe rather (≈øeeing the Radius undoeth in the one, what it doth in the other (which ineffect is to doe nothing at all) to da≈øh the one again≈øt the other, and race it out of both) then idely to expend time, and have the proportion pe≈øtred with unnece≈ø≈øarie termes. Thus from tho≈øe two re≈øolvers, foure termes being with rea≈øon ejected, we mu≈øt, for the finding out of the la≈øt in the ≈øecond Re≈øolver, effectuat as much by three, as formerly was on ≈øeven incumbent, which three being the fir≈øt, and ≈øecond termes in the fir≈øt row of proportionalls; and the third in the ≈øecond, the two Re≈øolvers Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîTo‚òûNyr, & To‚ÄîNeg‚ÄîSa‚òûnir are comprehended by this one Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîSa‚Äî‚òûNir, that is, As the ≈øine of one verticall to the Anti≈øine of an oppo≈øite; ≈øo the ≈øine of another verticall to the Anti≈øine of another oppo≈øite: and though the ≈øecond Re≈øolver doth import, that this other oppo≈øite is to be found out by the Anti≈øine of the perpendicular, and ≈øine of a ≈øecondarie verticall, yet doth it in nothing evince the coincidence of the two operations in one; becau≈øe the fir≈øt two termes of the Re≈øultative Analogie, doe adaequatly ≈øtand for the perpendicular, which I have proved already, and therefore the≈øe two in their proper places co-working with the third terme, according to the rule of proportion, have the ≈øelfe ≈øame influence, that the Perpendicular ≈øo ≈øeconded, hath upon the operatum.

Now, to contract the generality of this finall Re≈øolver, Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîSa‚òûNir, to all the particular Ca≈øes of this Mood, we mu≈øt ≈øay, When the given Angles are of the ≈øame affection, and the required diver≈øe, as in Da≈øimforaug, the fir≈øt ca≈øe, Sat‚ÄîNop‚ÄîSeud‚òûNob* Kir, that is, As the Sine of the double verticall to the Anti≈øine of the prime Cathetoppo≈øite: ≈øo the Sine of the ≈øecond verticaline (or verticall in the le≈ø≈øer rectangle) to the Anti≈øine of the next Cathetoppo≈øite, who≈øe complement to a ≈øemicircle is the Angle required.

But when, the affection of the given Angles being different, the perpendicular is made to fall without, as in Dadisforeug, the ≈øecond Ca≈øe of this Mood, the Re≈øolver thereof is particulari≈øed
thus, Saud‚ÄîNob‚ÄîSat‚òûNop * Ir, that is, As the Sine of the fir≈øt verticaline (or verticall in the rectanglet,) to the Sine complement of the neare≈øt Cathetoppo≈øite: ≈øo the Sine of the double verticall, to the Sine complement of the prime Cathetoppo≈øite, which is the Angle required.

‚ñ™ that is either the ≈øecond Subtendentine, the ≈øecond Subtendentall,
