Thirdly, Dakypambin, the Tenet of the la≈øt Ca≈øe, ≈øignifieth, that if the angle propo≈øed be ≈øharp, & that the demanded ≈øide be ≈øubjacent
to an obtu≈øe or blunt Angle, the Perpendicular falleth inwardly.

Having thus proceeded in the enumeration of the Cathetothetick Tenets of this Mood, according to the manner by me ob≈øerved in tho≈øe of all the former Di≈øergeticks, ≈øave the fir≈øt, I am confident the Reader (if he hath peru≈øed all the Tractat untill this place) will not think ≈øtrange why, Dakypambin being but the third, I ≈øhould call it the Tenet of the la≈øt Ca≈øe of this Mood; for though in Alamebna I ≈øpoke ≈øomewhat of every Amblygono≈øphericall Di≈øergetick Moods generall Cathetothetick maximes divi≈øion into foure e≈øpeciall Tenets, appropriable to ≈øo many ≈øeverall Ca≈øes: yet the fourth Ca≈øe, viz. that wherein all the Angles are homogeneall, whether blunt or ≈øharp, not being limited to any one Mood, but adaequatly extended to all the eight, it ≈øeemed to me more expedient to let its generality be known by mentioning it once or twice, then (by doing no more in effect) to make ≈øuperfluous repetitions; and, as in the fir≈øt Di≈øergetick Ca≈øe, for the Readers in≈øtruction, I did under the name of Simomatin, explicate the nature thereof: ≈øo, for his better remembrance, have I choo≈øed rather to ≈øhut up my Cathetothetick comment with the ≈øame di≈øcour≈øe wherewith I did begin it, then unnece≈ø≈øarily to weary him with frequent reiterations, and a tedious rehear≈øall of one and the ≈øame thing in all the ≈øix ≈øeverall intermediat Moods.

It is not ami≈ø≈øe now, that the perpendicularity of this Mood is di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, to con≈øider what the praeno≈øcendas thereof are, or the Quae≈øitas of the fir≈øt operation: but, as I ≈øaid in the la≈øt Mood, that there is no need to in≈øi≈øt ≈øo long upon the explication of tho≈øe praeno≈øcendas, whereof ample relation hath beene already made in ≈øome of my Proturgetick comments, as upon tho≈øe others, which, for being altogether different from ≈øuch as have beene formerly mentioned, claim (by the law of parity, in their imparity) right to a large di≈øcour≈øe apart, I will confine my pen upon this ≈øubject, within tho≈øe pre≈øcribed bounds, and ≈øeeing the fir≈øt Ba≈øal, the fir≈øt Ba≈øidion, and fir≈øt Co-ba≈øe, together with the Datas, whereby they are found out, viz. for the ≈øide, the fir≈øt ≈øubtendentall, the fir≈øt ≈øubtendentine, and the fir≈øt co ≈øubtendent; and for the Angle the prime Cathetoppo≈øite, the next Cathetoppo≈øite, and the fir≈øt Co-cathetoppo≈øite (the Datas being both for ≈øide and Angle
the ≈øame here, that they were in the former Mood) then the Sub≈øervient Ubamen, and its Re≈øolver Torp‚ÄîMu‚ÄîLag‚òûMyr, with the three peculiar Problemets thereto belonging, Utopat, ∆≤ dobaed, and Vthophaeth, are all and every one of them the ≈øame in this Mood of Errelome, that they were in the three foregoing Moods of Ammanepreb, Enerablo, and Ennerable, the≈øe being the onely foure Moods which have a laterall praeno≈øcendal identity, the Reader will not (in my opinion) be ≈øo prodigall of his owne labour, nor covetous of mine, that either he would put him≈øelfe, or me to any further paines, then have beene already be≈øtowed upon this matter by my ≈øelfe for his in≈øtruction; and therefore, leaving it for a ≈øuppo≈øed certainty, that the Praeno≈øcendas, or fir≈øt Ba≈øes (according to the nature of the Ca≈øe) cannot e≈øcape the Readers knowledge, by what hath beene by me delivered of them; I purpo≈øe here to give him notice, that the≈øe fore≈øaid fir≈øt Ba≈øes mu≈øt concurre with each its corre≈øpondent first Subtendent, to wit, the first ≈øubtendentall, the fir≈øt ≈øubtendentine, and fir≈øt co-≈øubtendent, digno≈øcible by the Characteri≈øticks of œÑ. Œ¥. Œ∏ for obtaining of the Perpendicular, of which operation, Vchener being the Sub≈øervient, by who≈øe Re≈øolver Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, the Problemets of Utaetca, Udaedca, and Uthaethca, are made manife≈øt, as to the ≈øame effect it remaines couched in my comment upon Ennerable, which is the onely Mood, that, with this of Errelome, hath a ≈øubtendentine and Ba≈øal Catheteuretick identity.

The ≈øecond work being thus perfected, the perpendicular, thereby found out, is to a≈ø≈øi≈øt one of the rere ≈øubtendents, in obtaining the illatitious terme of the maine qua≈øitum, corre≈øpondent thereto, di≈øcernable by the Characteri≈øticks or Figuratives of Œ¥. œÑ. Œ∏ or, more plainly to expre≈ø≈øe it, the Perpendicular mu≈øt concurre (according as the Ca≈øe requires it) with the ≈øecond ≈øubtendentine, the ≈øecond ≈øubtendentall, and ≈øecond co-≈øubtendent, (as you may ≈øee in the la≈øt Mood, the Datas of the Re≈øolutory partition whereof are the ≈øame as here) to find out three Ba≈øes, which, by ab≈øtracting the fir≈øt from another Ba≈øe, then by ab≈øtracting another Ba≈øe from the ≈øecond; and la≈øtly, by adding the third Ba≈øe to another, afford the ≈øumme and differences, which are the required Ba≈øes.

For the performance of this operation, the ≈øame Sub≈øervient
and Re≈øolver ≈øuffice, which ≈øerved for the la≈øt: ≈øo that Uchener ≈øub≈øerveth it, by who≈øe Re≈øolver Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, we are in≈øtructed how to explicate the Subdatoquaeres of Wdcathoed, Wtcathoet, and Wthcathoeth, or more orderly Cathwdoed, Cathwtoet, and Cathwthoeth.

All the three works being thus accompli≈øhed, the manner of conflating the la≈øt two in one re≈øts to be treated of; for the better perfecting of which de≈øigne, the two Re≈øolvers, or the ≈øame in its greate≈øt generality doubled, viz. Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, and Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, mu≈øt be interpreted: The truth is, both of them, as they ≈øound in their va≈øte≈øt extent of ≈øignification, expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame Analogy, without any difference, which is, As the Sine complement of a given ≈øide, to the Radius: ≈øo the Sine complement of a ≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement of another ≈øide: but when more contractedly, according to the ≈øpecification of the ≈øide, they doe ≈øuppone ≈øeverally, they ≈øhould be thus expounded; the fir≈øt, As the Sine complement of a fir≈øt Ba≈øe, to the totall Sine: ≈øo the Sine complement of a fir≈øt ≈øubtendent to the Sine complement of the Perpendicular: and the ≈øecond, As the Sine complement of the Perpendicular, to the totall Sine: ≈øo the Sine complement of a ≈øecond ≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement of a ≈øecond Ba≈øe, which u≈øhers the main quae≈øitum.

Now, the Perpendicular, and Radius, being both to be expelled the≈øe two fore≈øaid orders of proportionall termes, for the rea≈øons which, in the la≈øt preceding Mood, and ≈øome others before it, I have already mentioned, and which to repeat (further then that the ≈øympathy of this place with that may be manife≈øted in the tranf-≈øeating of multiplyers and dividers, occa≈øioned by the fourth terme in the fir≈øt rowes, being fir≈øt in the ≈øecond) is altogether unnece≈ø≈øary: in lieu of Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òû Nyr, and Neg‚ÄîTo‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, we may ≈øay, with as much truth, power, and efficacie, and farre more compendiou≈øly, Nu‚ÄîNe‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, that is, As the Sine complement of a ≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement of a ≈øide: ≈øo the ≈øine complement of another Subtendent, to the Sine complement of another ≈øide: Or, more particularly, and appliably to the pre≈øent Analogy, As the Sine complement of a fir≈øt ≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement of a fir≈øt Ba≈øe: ≈øo the Sine complement of a ≈øecond ≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement
of a ≈øecond Ba≈øe, illative to the quae≈øitum.

This theorem, or propo≈øition, comprehendeth in every point all that is in the two la≈øt operations, and, not tran≈øcending the number of the Ca≈øes of this Mood, is divided into ≈øo many finall Re≈øolvers; the fir≈øt whereof for the fir≈øt Ca≈øe, Dakyxamfor is, Nut‚ÄîNaet‚ÄîNwd‚òûNoedfr*Aet* Dyr, that is, As the Sine complement of the fir≈øt ≈øubtendent all, to the Sine complement of the first Ba≈øall‚ñ™ ≈øo the Sine complement of the ≈øecond ≈øubtendentine, to the Sine complement of the ≈øecond Ba≈øe; which ≈øubducted from the fir≈øt Ba≈øal, re≈øiduats the ≈øegment that is the ≈øide required.

The ≈øecond finall Re≈øolver of this Mood, and that which is for the ≈øecond Ca≈øe thereof, Dambyxamfor, is Nud‚ÄîNaed‚ÄîNwt‚òûNoetfr*Aed* Dyr, that is, As the Sine complement of the fir≈øt ≈øubtendentine, to the Sine complement of the fir≈øt Ba≈øidion: ≈øo the Sine complement of the ≈øecond ≈øubtendentall, to the Sine complement of the ≈øecond Ba≈øall; which, the fir≈øt Ba≈øidion being ≈øubtracted from it, leaves, for Remainder, or difference, that ≈øegment of the Ba≈øe, which is the ≈øide demanded.

The la≈øt finall Re≈øolver of this Mood (belonging to the third Ca≈øe, Dakypambin, as al≈øo to the fourth, Simomatin, (if what we have already ≈øpoke of that matter will permit us to call it the fourth) for Simomatin, together with the third Ca≈øe of every Mood, is ≈øtill re≈øolved by the la≈øt finall Re≈øolver thereof) is Nuth‚ÄîNaeth‚ÄîNwth‚òûNoethj*Aeth* Syr, that is, As the Sine complement of the fir≈øt co-≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement of the fir≈øt Co-ba≈øe: ≈øo the Sine complement, of the ≈øecond Co-≈øubtendent, or alterne ≈øubtendent, to the Sine complement of the ≈øecond Co-ba≈øe or alterne Ba≈øe; which added to the fir≈øt Co-ba≈øe, ≈øummes an Aggregat of ≈øubjacent ≈øides, which is the totall Ba≈øe, or ≈øide required.

The fundamentall ground of the truth of the≈øe Analogies, is in the fourth and la≈øt Amblygono≈øphericall Axiome, Niubprodne≈øver; (as we are made to under≈øtand by the ≈øecond determinater of its Directory Ennerra) for by the direct proportion that, among≈øt the terms thereof, is vi≈øible, (viz. betwixt the Sines complements of the ≈øubtendents, or Sides of the verticall Angles, and the ≈øegments of the Ba≈øes, and inver≈øedly) it is apparent, that this Mood doth no le≈ø≈øe firmely depend upon it, then that of Ennerable formerly explained.

Now, with rea≈øon doe I conjecture, that, without di≈øappointing the Reader of his expectation, I may here ≈øecurely make an end of this Trigonometricall Treati≈øe; becau≈øe of that Tri≈ø≈øotetrall Table, which comprehendeth all the My≈øteries, Axiomes, Principles, Analogies, and Precepts of the Science of Triangular Calculations, I have omitted no materiall point unexplained: yet ≈øeeing, for avoyding of prolixity, I was plea≈øed in my comment upon the eighth Loxogono≈øpherical Di≈øergeticks, barely to expre≈ø≈øe in their finall Re≈øolvers, the Analogie of the termes, without putting my ≈øelfe to the paines I took in my Sphericorectangulars, how to order the Logarithms,, and Antilogarithms of the proportionalls,, for obtaining of the maine Quae≈øitas, and that by having to the full explicated the variety of the proportions of the fore≈øaid Moods, and upon what ≈øeverall Axiomes they doe depend, thereby making the way more pervious, thorough Logarithmicall difficulties, for the Readers under≈øtanding, I deliberatly propo≈øed to my ≈øelfe this method at fir≈øt, and cho≈øe, rather then di≈øper≈øedly to treat of tho≈øe things in the glo≈ø≈øe (where, by rea≈øon of the di≈øturbed order, the corre≈øpondencie or reference to one another of the≈øe Sphericobliquangulary Datoquaeres, could not by any meanes have beene ≈øo conceivable) to ≈øummon their appearance to the Cata≈øtrophe of this Tractat, that, having them all in a front before us, we may the more ea≈øily judge of the ≈øemblance, or di≈ø≈øimilitude of their proportionalities,, and what affinity, or relation, whether of parity or imparity is among≈øt their re≈øpective proportionall terms: all which, both for intelligibility and memory, are quicklier apprehended, and longer retained, by being accumulatively re≈øerved to this place, then if they had beene each in its proper cell (though never ≈øo amply) di≈øcour≈øed upon apart.

Here therfore, that the Reader may take a generall view at once of all the Di≈øergetick Amblygono≈øphericall analogi≈øed ingredients, ready for Logarithmication, I have thought fit to ≈øet downe a Li≈øt of all the eight forenamed Moods, together with the Finall Re≈øolvers, in their ample≈øt extent thereto belonging, in the manner as followeth.

The≈øe being the eight Di≈øergeticks, attended by their Adaequat finall Re≈øolvers, it is not ami≈ø≈øe, that we examine them all one after another, and ≈øhew the Reader how, with the help of a convenient Logarithmicall Canon, he may ea≈øily out of the Analogie of the three fir≈øt termes of each of them, frame a computation apt for the finding out of a fourth proportionall, to every ≈øeverall ternarie corre≈øpondent: and ≈øo in order, beginning at the fir≈øt, we will deale with Say‚ÄîNag‚ÄîSa‚òûNir (which is the Adaequat finall Re≈øolver of Alamebna, and compo≈øed (as it is appropriated to the fir≈øt Mood of the Di≈øergeticks) of the Sines of verticals, and the Anti-≈øines of Cathetoppo≈øites) and ≈øo proceed therein, that by adding to the ≈øumme of the Sine of a verticall, and Co-≈øine of a Cathetoppo≈øite, the Arithmetical complement of the Sine of another verticall, we will be ≈øure (cutting off the ≈øupernumerary digit or digits towards the left) to obtaine the Co≈øine of the Cathetoppo≈øite required, which Cathetoppo≈øites and verticals are particulari≈øed according to the Ca≈øes of the Mood.

The ≈øecond is, Nag‚ÄîMu‚ÄîNa‚òûMur, which, running upon the Anti-≈øines of verticals, and the Co-tangents of ≈øubtendent ≈øides, ≈øheweth, that if to the Aggregat of a fir≈øt hypotenu≈øall Cotangent, and verticall Anti-≈øine, we joyne the Arithmeticall complement of the Anti-≈øine of another verticall, (ob≈øerving the u≈øuall pre≈øection) we cannot mi≈ø≈øe of the Co-tangent of the ≈øecond ≈øubtendent ≈øide required, which both ≈øecond, and fir≈øt ≈øubtendents have their peculiar denominations, according to the Ca≈øes of the Mood.

The third Re≈øolver is, Na‚ÄîSay‚ÄîNag‚òûSir, which, being nothing el≈øe but the fir≈øt inverted, runneth the ≈øame very way upon the Anti-≈øines of Cathetoppo≈øites, and ≈øines of verticals: and therefore doth the unradiu≈øed ≈øumme of the Anti-≈øine of a Cathetoppo≈øite, the ≈øine of a verticall, and the Arithmeticall complement of the Anti-≈øine of another Cathetoppo≈øite, afford the ≈øine of the verticall, illatitious to the Angle required; which
verticals and Cathetoppo≈øites are particulari≈øed according to the variety of the Ca≈øes of this Sindiforating Mood.

The fourth generall Re≈øolver is Ta‚ÄîTag‚ÄîSe‚òûSyr, which, cour≈øing on the Tangents of all the Cathetoppo≈øites, and ≈øines of all the Ba≈øes, evidenceth, that the ≈øumme of the Tangent of a Cathetoppo≈øite, and ≈øine of a fir≈øt Ba≈øe, added to the Arithmeticall complement of the Tangent of another Cathetoppo≈øite (unradiated) is the ≈øine of the ≈øecond Ba≈øe, illative to the ≈øegment required; which Ba≈øes (both first and ≈øecond) and Cathetoppo≈øites, are ≈øpeciali≈øed conform to the Ca≈øes of this Sindiforiuting Mood.

The fifth Re≈øolver is, Sei‚ÄîTag‚ÄîSe‚òûTir, which, compo≈øed of the ≈øines of the ≈øecond and fir≈øt Ba≈øes, and the Tangents of Cathetoppo≈øites, giveth us to know, that if to the ≈øumme of the ≈øine of a fir≈øt Ba≈øe, and the Tangent of a verticall, we adde the Arithmeticall complement of the ≈øine of a ≈øecond Ba≈øe, (not omitting the u≈øuall pre≈øection) we cannot faile of the Tangent of the Cathetoppo≈øite required, which Cathetoppo≈øites, and Ba≈øes, both fir≈øt and ≈øecond, are particulari≈øed according to the Ca≈øes of the Mood.

The ≈øixth generall Re≈øolver is, Neg‚ÄîNu‚ÄîNe‚òûNur, which, running along the Co-≈øines of all the Ba≈øes and Subtendents, ≈øheweth, that by the ≈øumme of the Co-≈øines of a ≈øecond Ba≈øe, and fir≈øt ≈øubtendent joyned with the Arithmeticall complement of the Co-≈øine of a fir≈øt Ba≈øe (if we ob≈øerve the cu≈øtomary pre≈øection) we find the ≈øecond Subtendent required, which both fir≈øt and ≈øecond Subtendents, together with the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Ba≈øes, are all of them particulari≈øed conforme to the Ca≈øes of the Mood.

The ≈øeventh Re≈øolver is, Mu‚ÄîNag‚ÄîMu‚òûNir, which, cour≈øing along the Anti-tangents of fir≈øt, and ≈øecond Subtendents, and the Anti-≈øines of verticals, ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Anti-tangent of a ≈øecond Subtendent, and Anti-≈øine of a verticall, together with the Arithmeticall complement of the Antitangent of a fir≈øt Subtendent (the u≈øuall pre≈øection being ob≈øerved) is the Anti-tangent of that verticall, which u≈øhers in the verticall required; all which, both Verticals, and Subtendents, both fir≈øt, and ≈øecond, have their peculiar denominations conforme to the Ca≈øes of this Sindiforating Mood.

The eighth and la≈øt generall Re≈øolver is, Nu‚ÄîNe‚ÄîNu‚òûNyr, which (running altogether upon Co-≈øines of Subtendents, and Ba≈øes, both fir≈øt, and ≈øecond of either, and is nothing el≈øe but the ≈øixth inverted) ≈øheweth, that the ≈øumme of the Co≈øines of a ≈øecond ≈øubtendent, and fir≈øt Ba≈øe, with the Arithmeticall complement of the co-≈øine of a fir≈øt Subtendent, (ob≈øerving the u≈øuall pre≈øection) affords the Co-≈øine of the ≈øecond Ba≈øe, illatitious to the ≈øegment required; which Ba≈øes and Subtendents, both fir≈øt, and ≈øecond, are peculiarly denominated according to the ≈øeverall Ca≈øes of this Sindiforiuting Mood.

Thus have I fini≈øhed the Logarithmication of the generall Re≈øolvers of the Loxogono≈øphericall Di≈øergeticks, ≈øo farre as is requi≈øite, wherein I often times mentioned the Arithmeticall complement of Sines, Co-≈øines, Tangents, and Co-tangents: and though I ≈øpoke of that purpo≈øe ≈øufficiently in my Sphericorectangular comments, yet, for the Readers better remembrance thereof, I will once more define them here.

The Arithmeticall complements of Sines are Co-≈øecants; of Co-≈øines, Secants; of Tangents, Co-tangents; and of Co-tangents, Tangents; each being the others complement to the double Radius: but if ≈øuch a Canon were framed, wherein the ≈øingle Radius is left out of all Secants, and Tangents of major Arches, then would each be the others complement to the ≈øingle Radius, and all Logarithmicall operations in que≈øtions of Trigonometry ≈øo ea≈øily performable by addition onely, that ≈øeldome would the pre≈øectionall digit exceed an unit.

Having already ≈øaid ≈øo much of the≈øe eight Di≈øergeticks, I will conclude my di≈øcour≈øe of them with a ≈øummary delineation of the eight ≈øeverall Concordances which I ob≈øerved among≈øt them; for either they re≈øemble one another in the Datas of their Moods, or in their Proturgetick operations, or in their dependance upon the ≈øame Axiome, or in the work of perpendicular finding, or in their Datas for the main demand, or in their materiall Quae≈øitas (though diver≈øly endowed) or in their inver≈øion, or la≈øtly in their ≈øindiforation, which affinity is onely betwixt two paires of them, as the fir≈øt two among≈øt two quaternaries apeece, and the next five between foure couples each one, the brief hypotypo≈øis of all which is here expo≈øed to the view of the Reader.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
div.p:
WHat concerneth the re≈øolving of all manner of Triangles, whether plain, or Sphericall, Rectangular, or Obliquangular, being now (conform to my promi≈øe in the Title) to the ful explained, commented on, perfected, and with all po≈ø≈øible brevity, and per≈øpicuity, in all its ab≈øtru≈øe≈øt and mo≈øt difficult Secrets, from the very fir≈øt principles of the Science it ≈øelfe, made manife≈øt, proved, and convincingly demon≈øtrated; I will here ≈øhut up my di≈øcour≈øe, and bring this Tractat to a period: which I may do with the more alacrity, in that I am confident, there is no Precept belonging to that faculty which is not herein included, or reducible thereto: and therefore (I beleeve) the judicious Reader will not be fru≈øtrate of his expectation, though by cutting the threed of my Glo≈ø≈øe, I doe not illu≈øtrate what I have written with variety of examples; ≈øeeing practically to treat of Triangulary calculations, in applying their doctrine to u≈øe, were to digre≈ø≈øe from the purpo≈øe in hand, and incroach upon the ≈øubject of other Sciences; a priviledge, which I mu≈øt decline, as repugnant to the ≈øcope propo≈øed to my ≈øelfe, in keeping this book within the ≈øpeculative bounds of Trigonometry: for, as Logica utens, is the Science to the which it is applyed, and not Logick: So doth not the matter of Trigonometry, exceed the Theory of a Triangle: And as Arithmeticall, Geometricall, Astronomicall, Phy≈øicall, and Metaphy≈øicall definitions, divi≈øions, and argumentations, are no part of the Art that in≈øtructeth how to define, divide, and argue, nor matter incumbent to him that teacheth it: even
≈øo, by divulging this Treati≈øe, doe I pre≈øent the Reader with a Key, by meanes whereof he may enter into the chiefe≈øt trea≈øures of the Mathematicall Sciences; for the which, in ≈øome mea≈øure, I de≈øerve thanks, although I help him not to un≈øhut the Coffers wherein they lie inclo≈øed: for, if the Lord chamberlain of the Kings hou≈øhold ≈øhould give me a Key, made to open all the doores of the Court, I could not but graciou≈øly accept of it, though he did not goe along with me to try how it might fit every lock. The application is ≈øo palpable, that, not minding to in≈øi≈øt therein, I will here ≈øtop the current of my Pen, and by a circulary conclu≈øion, ending where I begun, certifie the Reader, that if he intend to approve him≈øelfe an Arti≈øt in matters of Pleu≈øiotechnie, Poliechyrologie, Co≈ømography, Geography, A≈øtronomy, Geode≈øie, Gnomonicks, Sciography, Catoptricks, Dioptricks, and many other mo≈øt exqui≈øite Arts and Sciences, Practical and Theoretick, his ≈øure≈øt cour≈øe, for attaining to ≈øo much knowledge, is to be well ver≈øed in Trigonometry, to under≈øtand this Treatife aright, revolve all the pa≈ø≈øages thereof, ruminate on the Table, and peru≈øe the Tri≈ø≈øotetras.

div.head: A Lexicidion of ≈øome of the harde≈øt words, that occurre in the di≈øcour≈øe of this in≈øtitution Trigonometricall.

div.p: BEing certainly per≈øwaded, that a great many good ≈øpirits ply Trigonometry, that are not ver≈øed in the learned Tongues, I thought fit, for their encouragement, to ≈øubjoyne here the explication of the mo≈øt important of tho≈øe Greek, and Latin termes, which, for the more efficacy of expre≈ø≈øion, I have made u≈øe of in this Treati≈øe: in doing whereof, that I might both in≈øtruct the Reader, and not weary him, I have endeavoured per≈øpicuity with ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe: though (I ≈øpeak it ingenuou≈øly) to have been more prolixe therin, could have co≈øt but very little labor to me, who have already bin pretty well ver≈øed in the like, as may appear by my Etymologicall dictionary of above twenty ≈øeven thou≈øand proper names, mentioned in the Lemmas of my ≈øeverall Volums of Epigrams, the words whereof are for the mo≈øt part ab≈øtru≈øer, derived from moe Languages, and more liable to large, and ample interpretations. However (caeteris paribus) brevity is to be preferred; therefore let us proceed to the Vocabulary in hand.

div.head: THE LEXICIDION.

list.head: A.
list.label: ACute,
list.item: comes from Acuo, acuere, to ≈øharpen, and is ≈øaid of an Angle, who≈øe including ≈øides, the more that its mea≈øure is le≈ø≈øe then a Quadrant, have their concur≈øive, and angulary point the more penetrative, ≈øharp, keen and pierceing: Whence an acutangled triangle.
list.label: Adaequat,
list.item: is that, which comprehendeth to the full, whatever is in the thing to the which it is compared, and for the mo≈øt part in my Tri≈ø≈øotetras is ≈øaid of the generall finall Re≈øolvers, in relation to the Moods re≈øolved by them. It is compounded of Ad, and aequo, aequare, parem facere, to make one thing altogether like, or equall to another.
list.label: Adjacent,
list.item: ≈øignifieth to lie neare, and clo≈øe, and is applyed both to ≈øides, and Angles, in which ≈øen≈øe likewi≈øe I make u≈øe of the words adjoyning the, conterminat, or conterminall with, annexed to, intercepted in, and other ≈øuch like, for the more variety, as adherent, bounding, bordering, and ≈øo forth: It comes from Adjaceo, Adjacere, to lie neere unto, as the words Ad and jaceo, which are the parts whereof it is compounded, most per≈øpicuou≈øly declare.
list.label: Additionall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Line, which, in my comment, is indifferently called the Line of Addition, the Line of continuation, the extrin≈øecall Line, the exce≈ø≈øe of the Secant above the Radius, the Refiduum, or the new Secant: it comes from Addo, Addere, which is compounded of Ad, and do, to put to and augment.
list.label: Affection,
list.item: is the nature, pa≈ø≈øion, and quality of an Angle, and con≈øi≈øteth either in the obtu≈øity, acutene≈ø≈øe, or rectitude thereof: It is a verball from Afficio, affeci, affectum, compounded of ad, and facio.
list.label: Aggregat,
list.item: is the ≈øumme, totall, or re≈øult of an Addition, and is compounded of Ad, and grex; for, as the Shepheard gathers his Sheep into a flock, ≈øo doth the Arithmetician compact his numbers to be added into a ≈øumme.
list.label: Alternat,
list.item: is ≈øaid of Angles, made by a Line cutting two or more parallels, which Angles may be properly called ≈øo; becau≈øe they differ in nothing el≈øe but their ≈øituation; for if the ≈øectionary Line, to the which I ≈øuppo≈øe the parallels to be fixed, have the highest and lowe≈øt points thereof to interchange their ≈øites, by a motion progre≈ø≈øive towards the roome of the under Alternat, and terminating in that of the upper one, we will find, that both the inclination of the Lines towards one another, and the quality of the Angles, will, notwith≈øtanding that alteration, be the ≈øame as before; hence it is that they are called alternat, becau≈øe there is no other difference betwixt them: or, if alternat be taken (as arithmetically it is) for that proportion, wherein the Antecedent is compared to the Antecedent, and the Con≈øequent to the Con≈øequent, the ≈øen≈øe will likewi≈øe hold in the fore≈øaid Angles; for if by the paralleli≈øme of two right Lines, cut with a third, two blunt, and two keen Angles be produced (as mu≈øt needs, unle≈ø≈øe the Secant line be to the parallels a perpendicular) the keen or acute Angle will be to its complement, or ≈øucce≈øsively following obtu≈øe Angle, as the other acute unto its following obtu≈øe; therefore alternly, as the Antecedents are to one another, viz. the Acute to the Acute: ≈øo the Con≈øequents, the obtu≈øe to the obtu≈øe. And if the Angles be right, the direct, and alternat proportion is one and the ≈øame; the third, and fourth terms of the Analogy being in nothing different from the fir≈øt, and ≈øecond.
list.label: Ambient,
list.item: is taken for any of the legs of a rectangle, or the including, containing, or comprehending ≈øides of the right Angle: it comes from Ambio, Ambire, which is compounded of Am and eo, i. e. circumeo: and more properly applied to both, then to any one of them, though u≈øually it be u≈øurped for one alone, vide Leg.
list.label: Amblygonian,
list.item:
is ≈øaid of obtu≈øe angled Triangles, and Amblygono≈øphericall of obtu≈øe ≈øphericals: It is compo≈øed of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
angulus.
list.label: Amfractuo≈øities,
list.item: are taken here for the cranklings, windings, turnings, and involutions belonging to the equi≈øoleary Scheme; of am and frango, quod ≈øit qua≈øi via crebris maeandris undequaque interrupta.
list.label: Analogy,
list.item: ≈øignifieth an equality of proportion, a likene≈ø≈øe of rea≈øons, a conveniencie, or habitude betwixt termes: It is compounded of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , aequaliter, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ratio.
list.label: Analytick,
list.item: re≈øolutory, and is ≈øaid of tho≈øe things that are re≈øolved into their fir≈øt principles, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , re, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øolvo.
list.label: Antilogarithm,
list.item: is the Logarithm of the complement; as for example, the Anti-logarithm of a Sine is the Logarithm of the Sine complement, vide Logarithm.
list.label: Anti-≈øecant,
list.item: Anti-≈øine, and Anti-tangent, are the complements of the Secant, Sine, and Tangent, and are called ≈øometime Co-≈øecant, Co-≈øine, and Co-tangent: they have anti prefixed, becau≈øe they are not in the ≈øame colume, and co, becau≈øe they are in the next to it.
list.label: Apodictick,
list.item:
is that, which is demonstrative, and giveth evident proofs of the truth of a conclu≈øion; of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , mon≈øtro, o≈øtendo, unde
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , demon≈øtratio.
list.label: Area,
list.item: is the capacity of a Figure, and whole content thereof.
list.label: Arch,
list.item: or Ark, is the ≈øegment of a circumference le≈ø≈øe then a ≈øemicircle: major Arch is above 45. degrees, a minor Arch, le≈ø≈øe then 45. vide Circle.
list.label: Arithmeticall
list.item: complement, is the difference betweene the Logarithm to be ≈øub≈øtracted, and that of the double, or ≈øingle Radius.
list.label: Artificiall
list.item: numbers, are the Logarithms, and artificiall Sine the Logarithm of the Sine.
list.label: Axiome,
list.item: is a maxim, tenet, or nece≈ø≈øary principle, whereupon the Science of a thing is grounded: it cometh from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , dignus; becau≈øe ≈øuch things are worthy our knowledge.

list.head: B.
list.label: BA≈øall,
list.item: adjectively is that, which belongeth to the Ba≈øe, or the ≈øubjacent ≈øide, but ≈øubstantively the great Ba≈øe.
list.label: Ba≈øangulary,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Angles at the Ba≈øe.
list.label: Ba≈øidion,
list.item: or ba≈øet, is the little Ba≈øe, all which come from the Greek word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
list.label: Ba≈øiradius,
list.item: is the totall Sine of that Arch, a Segment whereof is the Ba≈øe of the propo≈øed ≈øphericall Triangle.
list.label: Bi≈øected,
list.item: and Bi≈øegment, are ≈øaid of lines cut into two equall parts: it comes from bi≈øeco, bi≈øecare, bi≈øectum, bi≈øegmen.
list.label: Bluntne≈ø≈øe,
list.item: or flatne≈ø≈øe, is the obtu≈øe affection of Angles.
list.label: Bucarnon,
list.item: by this name is entitled the ≈øeven and fortieth propo≈øition of the fir≈øt of the elements of Euclid; becau≈øe of the oxe, or, (as ≈øome ≈øay) the hecatomb which Pythagoras, for gladne≈ø≈øe of the invention, ≈øacrificed unto the gods: of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , bos, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , vici≈ø≈øim aliquid capio; they being (as it is ≈øuppo≈øed) well plea≈øed with that acknowledgement of his thankfulne≈ø≈øe for ≈øo great a favour, as that was, which he received from them: you may ≈øee the propo≈øition in the ≈øeventeenth of my Apodicticks.

list.head: C.
list.label: CAnon,
list.item: is taken here for the Table of Sines and Tangents, or of their Logarithms: it properly ≈øignifieth the needle or tongue of a balance, and metaphorically a rule, whereby things are examined.
list.label: Ca≈øes,
list.item: are the parts wherein a Mood is divided from cado.
list.label: Cathetos,
list.item: is a Perpendicular line, from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , demitto, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
list.label: Catheteuretick,
list.item: is concerning the finding out of the Perpendicular of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , invenio.
list.label: Cathetoba≈øall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Concordances of Loxogono≈øphericall Moods, in the Datas of the Perpendicular, and the Ba≈øe, for finding out of the maine quae≈øitum.
list.label: Cathetoppo≈øite,
list.item: is the Angle oppo≈øite to the Perpendicular; it is a hybrid or mungrell word, compo≈øed of the Greek „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and Latin oppo≈øitus.
list.label: Cathetorabdos,
list.item: or Cathetoradius, is the totall Sine of that Arch, a Segment whereof is the Cathetos, or Perpendicular of the propo≈øed Orthogono≈øphericall.
list.label: Cathetothe≈øis,
list.item: and cathetothetick are ≈øaid of the determinat po≈øition of the Perpendicular, which is ≈øometimes expre≈ø≈øed by cathetology, in≈øtructing us how it ≈øhould be demitted: of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , pono, colloco.
list.label: Cathetoverticall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Concordances of Loxogono≈øphericall Moods in the Datas of the perpendicular, and the verticall Angle in the la≈øt operation.
list.label: Catoptrick,
list.item: the Science of per≈øpective, from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , per≈øpicio, cerno.
list.label: Characteri≈øtick,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the letters, which are the notes and marks of di≈øtinction, called ≈øometimes figuratives, or determinaters, from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øculpo, imprimo.
list.label: Circles,
list.item: great circles are tho≈øe which bi≈øect the Sphere, le≈ø≈øer Circles tho≈øe which not.
list.label: Circular
list.item: parts, are in oppo≈øition to the reall and naturall parts of a Triangle.
list.label: Circumjacent,
list.item: things which lie about, of circum and jaceo.
list.label: Coale≈øcencie,
list.item: a growing together, a compacting of two things in one; it is ≈øaid of the la≈øt two operations of the Loxogono≈øphericals conflated into one, from coale≈øco or coalco, of con and alo.
list.label: Coba≈øe,
list.item: a fellow Ba≈øe, or that which with another Ba≈øe hath a common Perpendicular, of con and ba≈øis.
list.label: Cocathetoppo≈øite,
list.item: is ≈øaid of two, Angles at the Ba≈øe, oppo≈øite to one and the ≈øame Cathetos.
list.label: Coincidence,
list.item: a falling together upon the ≈øame thing, from coincido, of con, and incido, ex in, & cado.
list.label: Comment,
list.item: is an interpretation, or expo≈øition of a thing, and comes from commini≈øcor, commini≈øci, mentionem facere.
list.label: Compacted,
list.item: joyned, and knit together, put in one; from compingo, compegi, compactum, vide Coale≈øcencie.
list.label: Complement,
list.item: ≈øignifieth the perfecting that which a thing wanteth, and u≈øually is that, which an Angle or a Side wanteth of a Quadrant, or 90. degrees: and of a Semicircle, or 180. from compleo, complere, to fill up.
list.label: Concur≈øe,
list.item: is the meeting of lines, or of the ≈øides of a Triangle, from concurro, concur≈øum.
list.label: Conflated,
list.item: compacted, joyned together, from conflo, conflatum, conflare, to blow together, vide Incha≈øed.
list.label: Con≈øectary,
list.item: is taken here for a Corollary, or rather a ≈øecondary Axiome, which dependeth on a prime one, & being deduced from it, doth nece≈ø≈øarily follow. From con≈øector, con≈øectaris, the frequentative of con≈øequor.
list.label: Con≈øound,
list.item: to ≈øound with another thing; it is ≈øaid of con≈øonants, which have no vocality without the help of the vowell.
list.label: Con≈øtitutive,
list.item: is ≈øaid of tho≈øe things, which help to frame, make, and build up: From con≈øtituo, of con and ≈øtatuo.
list.label: Con≈øtitutive
list.item: ≈øides, the ingredient ≈øides of a Triangle.
list.label: Con≈øtructive
list.item: parts, are tho≈øe, whereof a thing is built, and framed: From con≈øtruo, con≈øtructum, to heap together, and build up, of con and ≈øtrues.
list.label: Conterminall,
list.item:
is that which bordereth with, and joyneth to a thing, of
con and terminus, vide Adjacent, or In≈øident.
list.label: Cordes,
list.item: and cordall, are ≈øaid of ≈øubten≈øes metaphorically; becau≈øe the Arches and ≈øubten≈øes are as the bow and ≈øtring: chorda, comes of the Greek word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , inte≈øtinum, ilia, quia ex illis chordae conficiuntur.
list.label: Correctangle,
list.item: that is one which, with another rectangle, hath a common Perpendicular.
list.label: Corre≈øpondent,
list.item: that which an≈øwereth with, and hath a reference to another thing, of con and re≈øpondeo.
list.label: Co≈øinoco≈øinall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Concordances of Loxogono≈øphericall Moods, agreeing, in that the termes of their finall Re≈øolvers run upon Co≈øines.
list.label: Co≈ømography,
list.item: is taken here for the Science whereby is de≈øcribed the cele≈øtiall Globe, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
list.label: Co≈øubtendent,
list.item: is the ≈øubtendent of a correctangle, or that which with another is ≈øub≈øterned to two right Angles, made by the demi≈ø≈øion of one and the ≈øame Perpendicular.
list.label: Coverticall,
list.item: is the fellow top Angle, from whence the Perpendicular falleth.

list.head: D.
list.label: DAta,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the parts of a Triangle, which are given us, whether they be ≈øides or Angles, or both, of do, datum, dare.
list.label: Datimi≈øta,
list.item: are tho≈øe Datas, which are neither Angles onely, nor ≈øides onely, but Angles, and ≈øides intermixedly: of data, and mi≈øta, from mi≈øceo.
list.label: Datangulary,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Concordances of tho≈øe Moods, for the obtaining of who≈øe Praeno≈øcendas, we have no other Datas, but Angles, unto the fore≈øaid Moods common.
list.label: Datapurall,
list.item: comes from datapura, which be tho≈øe Datas, that are either meerly Angles, or meerly ≈øides.
list.label: Datolaterall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of the Concordances of tho≈øe Moods, for the obtaining of who≈øe Praeno≈øcendas, the ≈øame ≈øides ≈øerve for Datas.
list.label: Datoquaere,
list.item: is the very Problem it ≈øelfe, wherein two or three things are given, and a third or fourth required, as by the compo≈øition of the word appears.
list.label: Dati≈øterurgetick,
list.item:
is ≈øaid of tho≈øe Moods which agree in the Datas of the la≈øt work: of data,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , po≈øtremum, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , opus.
list.label: Demi≈ø≈øion,
list.item: is a letting fall of the Perpendicular: from demitto; demi≈ø≈øum.
list.label: Determinater,
list.item: is the characteristick or figurative letter of a directory: from determinare, to pre≈øcribe and limit.
list.label: Diagonall,
list.item: taken ≈øub≈øtantively, or diagonie, is a line drawn from one Angle to another, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ what the diagonie is in ≈øurfaces, the axle is in ≈øolids.
list.label: Diagrammati≈øe,
list.item: to make a Scheme or Diagram, from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , delineo.
list.label: Diatypo≈øis,
list.item: is a briefe ≈øummary de≈øcription, and delineation of a thing: or the couching of a great deale of matter, for the in≈øtruction of the Reader, in very little bounds, and in a mo≈øt neat and convenient order: from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in≈øtituo, item melius di≈øpono, vide „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
list.label: Diodot,
list.item: is Pythagora≈øes Bucarnon, or the gift be≈øtowed on him by the gods: of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the genitive of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , datus, from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , do, vide Bucarnon.
list.label: Dioptrick,
list.item: the art of taking heights and di≈øtances, from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ pervidendo, altitudinem dimen≈øionemque turrium & murorum exploro.
list.label: Directly,
list.item: is ≈øaid of two rowes of proportionals, where the fir≈øt terme of the fir≈øt row, is to the fir≈øt of the ≈øecond, as the la≈øt of the first, is to the la≈øt of the ≈øecond.
list.label: Directory,
list.item: is that which pointeth out the Moods dependent on an Axiome.
list.label: Di≈øcrepant,
list.item: different, di≈ø≈øonant, id e≈øt, diver≈øo modo crepare.
list.label: Di≈øergeticks,
list.item: of two operations, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
list.label: Document,
list.item: in≈øtruction, from doceo.

list.head: E.
list.label: ELucidation,
list.item: a clearing, explaining, re≈øolving of a doubt, and commenting on ≈øome ob≈øcure pa≈ø≈øage, from elucido, elucidare.
list.label: Energie,
list.item: efficacie, power, force; from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , qui in opere e≈øt, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , opus.
list.label: Enodandum,
list.item: that which is to be re≈øolved and explicated, declared, and made manife≈øt, from enodo, enodare, to unknit, or cut away the knot.
list.label: Equation,
list.item: or rather aequation, a making equall, from aequo, aequare.
list.label: Equiangularity,
list.item: is that affection of Triangles, whereby their Angles are equall.
list.label: Equicrurall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of Triangles, who≈øe legs or ≈øhanks are equall; of aequale, and crus, cruris; leg being taken here for the thigh and leg.
list.label: Equilaterall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of Triangles, which have all their ≈øides, ≈øhanks, or legs equall, of aequale and latus, lateris.
list.label: Equipollencie,
list.item: is a ≈øamene≈ø≈øe, or at lea≈øt an equality of efficacie, power, vertue, and energie; of aequus and polleo.
list.label: Equi≈øolea,
list.item: and Equi≈øolearie, are ≈øaid of the grand Orthogono ≈øphericall Scheme; becau≈øe of the re≈øemblance it hath with a hor≈øe-≈øhooe, and may in that ≈øen≈øe be to this purpo≈øe applied with the ≈øame metaphoricall congruencie, whereby it is ≈øaid, that the royall army at Edge-hill was imbatteld in a half-moon.
list.label: Equivalent,
list.item: of as much worth and vertue, of aequus and valeo.
list.label: Erected,
list.item: is ≈øaid of Perpendiculars, which are ≈øet or rai≈øed upright upon a Ba≈øe, from erigere, to rai≈øe up, or ≈øet aloft.
list.label: Externall,
list.item: extrin≈øecall, exteriour, outward, or outer, are ≈øaid oftest of Angles, which being without the Area of a Triangle, are comprehended by two of its ≈øhanks meeting or cutting one another, accordingly as one or both of them are protracted beyond the extent of the figure.

list.head: F.
list.label: FAciendas,
list.item: are the things which are to be done: faciendum is the gerund of facio.
list.label: Figurative,
list.item: is the ≈øame thing as Characteri≈øtick, and is applied to tho≈øe letters which doe figure and point us out a re≈øemblance and di≈øtinction in the Moods.
list.label: Figures,
list.item: are taken here for tho≈øe partitions of Trigonometry, which are divided into Moods.
list.label: Flat,
list.item: is ≈øaid of obtu≈øe, or blunt Angles.
list.label: Forwardly,
list.item: is ≈øaid of Analogies, progre≈øsive from the fir≈øt terme to the la≈øt.
list.label: Fundamentall,
list.item: is ≈øaid of rea≈øons, taken from the fir≈øt grounds and principles of a Science.

list.head: G.
list.label: GEode≈øie,
list.item: the Art of Surveying, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , terra, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , divido, partior.
list.label: Geography,
list.item:
the Science of the Terre≈øtriall Globe, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ

div.head: The finall Conclu≈øion.
div.p: IF the novelty of this my Invention be acceptable (as I doubt not but it will) to the mo≈øt Learned, and judicious Mathematicians, I have already reaped all the benefit I expected by it, and ≈øhall hereafter, (God willing) without hope of any further recompence, cheerfully under-goe more laborious employments, of the like nature, to doe them ≈øervice: But as for ≈øuch, who, either under≈øtanding it not, or vain-gloriou≈øly being accu≈øtomed to Critici≈øe on the Works of others, will pre≈øume to carp therein at what they cannot amend, I pray God to illuminate their Judgements, and rectifie their Wils, that they may know more, and cen≈øure le≈ø≈øe; for ≈øo by forbearing detraction, the venom whereof mu≈øt needs reflect upon them≈øelves, they will come to approve better of the endeavours of tho≈øe, that wi≈øh them no harme.
